Arcanine.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description:
• A unique combination of Intimidate, Extreme Speed and multiple support tools make Arcanine a versatile and unpredictable defensive option.

  • Extreme Speed: Even on a defensive set, Extreme Speed's strong base power and priority combined with Arcanine's naturally high Attack make it a potent cleaning tool.

  • Roar: Roar lets Arcanine phaze out troublesome set-up foes that are hard for teammates to switch into, such as Wo-Chien and Garganacl.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze's speed control can be used to set up your own offense for a countersweep.

  • EV Spread: After Intimidate, the given EV spread lets Arcanine avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Crunch and Baxcalibur's Earthquake. The HP investment minimizes Stealth Rock damage when not running Heavy-Duty Boots, and the Speed investment outspeeds Adamant Breloom.

Other Options

  • Snarl: This move lets Arcanine pester special attackers that switch into it, potentially letting it stay in longer or ease a switch to a teammate.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: As a defensive switch-in with a Stealth Rock weakness, Arcanine heavily favors Heavy-Duty Boots to remove said weakness.

  • Rocky Helmet: Against targets like Chien-Pao, Arcanine can rack up passive chip damage.

  • Leftovers: Passive recovery is a valuable asset to have on a defensive Pokemon, but since Arcanine is an Intimidate user that switches a lot, Leftovers doesn't always have enough turns to produce good value.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Terastallization can do a lot to further improve Arcanine's unique set of attributes, but it's not necessarily something that Arcanine needs to function.

  • Normal: Tera Normal gives Arcanine even more cleaning power by boosting Extreme Speed. It's also a nice pinch option for blocking Ghost-type moves, as Flutter Mane and Mimikyu are often forced to use them due to Arcanine's Fairy resistance.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy provides defensive insurance against some of the hardest hitting Choice Band users, such as Tera Dark Chien-Pao and Outrage Dragonite.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• The given EV spread minimizes Stealth Rock damage, and the Speed investment lets Arcanine outspeed Adamant Tyranitar by 2 points.

  • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Cloyster.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
• Shell Smash and Skill Link more than make up for Cloyster's weak Attack stat, making it a formidable sweeper that Focus Sash and Mimikyu can't easily stop.

  • Ice Shard: Priority may seem like overkill, but it helps pick off weakened threats without setup. It also gets around priority attacks from Breloom, Dragapult, and Meowscarada after a Shell Smash.

  • Rock Blast: This is Closyer's best shot at dealing with the many Tera Fires that resist Icicle Spear, as well as OHKOing Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle, and Iron Moth.

  • Drill Run: This hits Gholdengo and other Steel-types hard without needing to Terastallize.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: Adamant is the preferred nature to maximize offensive power, as a single Shell Smash lets you outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. However, Cloyster is in the same speed tier as Breloom, so Jolly is a consideration if you want to minimize Speed tie scenarios in that matchup.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: As a Focus Sash user, Cloyster wants to avoid using Tera when possible, but opposing priority attacks and defensive typings can sometimes make it a necessity.

  • Ghost: Since Cloyster will often be at extremely low health after Shell Smash, Tera Ghost helps it avoid getting revenge killed by Breloom's Mach Punch and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed. It also provides coverage against Gholdengo with Tera Blast.

  • Ice: The increased damage from Tera Ice makes it very difficult for Pokemon to wall Cloyster without resisting it, with even Corviknight getting OHKOed by +2 Adamant Icicle Spear after Stealth Rock damage.

  • Ground: Volt Switch users like Rotom-W love to take Cloyster down to its Sash and pivot to a priority attacker; Tera Ground both immunes the damage and prevents the switch, giving Cloyster significant momentum with a free turn to Shell Smash. It also lets Cloyster challenge defensive Gholdengo, blocking Thunder Wave and giving +2 Adamant Drill Run a strong chance to OHKO.

  • Fire: While Tera Fire Tera Blast actually does less damage to Corviknight than Tera Ice Icicle Spear, Tera Fire otherwise helps Cloyster muscle past Steel-types it traditionally struggles to beat, such as Scizor.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is a niche option that offers no offensive benefits to Cloyster, but it does prevent Mimikyu and Gallade from revenge killing it with Shadow Sneak.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Considering Cloyster's paper thin Special Defense, Focus Sash gives Cloyster by far the most set up opportunities.

  • King's Rock: King's Rock is a risky option that doesn’t help Cloyster set up, but it does give Icicle Spear and Rock Blast a 41% chance of flinching.

Gengar.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Disruptor
sets.description:
• Gengar's useful immunities and great support movepool give it a niche as an incredibly disruptive Pokemon, especially if taking the correct predictive risks.

  • Destiny Bond: Destiny Bond is excellent at making foes second guess attacking Gengar. When slower foes don't take the bait and use a setup move, Gengar can punish them with Encore.

  • Encore: Gengar's excellent speed makes it an especially disruptive user of Encore, being able to disrupt key threats such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

  • Icy Wind: Icy Wind's Speed control can give Gengar the upper hand against fast Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane, and lets Gengar outspeed faster threats that it may want to Destiny Bond, such as Meowscarada.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave is great at crippling faster sweepers if Gengar's Focus Sash is intact, and punishing fast, common switch-ins such as Roaring Moon.

  • Sludge Bomb: This covers Meowscarada and Fairy-types, in addition to being Gengar's most powerful attack.

  • Dazzling Gleam In addition to OHKOing Hydreigon after Stealth Rock damage, Dazzling Gleam is an appealing secondary STAB move when using Tera Fairy.

  • Focus Blast: Focus Blast is Gengar's best shot at beating Kingambit outside of Destiny Bond.

Other Options

  • Will-O-Wisp Gengar does a great job of burning bulky sweepers that Gengar can be forced to Destiny Bond against, such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Tera Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal Gengar can turn slower Ghost-types such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Annihilape into easy Encore targets.

  • Fairy: A Dragon-type immunity gives Gengar new Encore targets and better threatens Dragon-types.

  • Flying: Earthquake is a common attack against Gengar, so Tera Flying can turn the tables effectively. It also takes advantage of common Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type lets Gengar surprise Espathra, letting it Encore Stored Power and potentially ruin its sweep.

sets.name: FIREFIGHTER (Defensive)
sets.description:
• Will-O-Wisp and Intimidate make Paldean Tauros-F a potent check to physical attackers, notably enabling it reliably check Chien-Pao and Kingambit.

  • Raging Bull: This provides a powerful STAB attack that can also break screens, allowing Paldean Tauros-F’s teammates to clean up more easily.

  • Body Press Body Press is valuable because unlike Close Combat, it doesn’t cause defense drops.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb allows Paldean Tauros-F to check Volcarona despite its meager Special Defense.

  • Bulk Up: While this set is unlikely to sweep, Bulk Up does give Paldean Tauros-F a good way to punish foes that attempt to sacrifice their Pokemon to it.

  • Tera Dependency - Very Situational: Paldean Tauros-F should generally avoid Terastallizing, as its typing is a big part of what lets it act as such a sturdy check to Kingambit and other massive threats, such as Baxcalibur.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry / Figy Berry: A quick burst of recovery from a berry fits playing this set a bit more recklessly.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This allows Paldean Tauros-F to switch around more freely in after entry hazards are set.

  • Rocky Helmet: Paldean Tauros-F tends to force a lot of switches, so Rocky Helmet lets it get some useful chip damage when switching into moves like Chien-Pao's Crunch.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a high value item that other Pokemon want, but the gradual recovery is useful.

sets.name: Offensive Screen Smasher
sets.description:
• Paldean Tauros-F is fast enough to outspeed key threats such as Mimikyu and Modest Chi-Yu, making an offensive set viable.

  • Raging Bull versus Flare Blitz: Raging Bull might not be as powerful as Flare Blitz, but its ability to break Reflect and Light Screen give Paldean Tauros-F a unique niche.

  • Flame Charge versus Trailblaze: Flame Charge gives Paldean Tauros-F an unexpected late-game win condition, letting it outspeed threats such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. Trailblaze is often weaker, but the greater chip dagainst against Water-types such as Azumarill can be beneficial.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's speed control is useful when sacrificing Paldean Tauros-F against a threat and prevents Dragonite from getting easy Speed boosts.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Despite this set's offensive nature, Will-O-Wisp is good for punishing Dragonite, Dragapult, and slower foes that may Terrastallize, such as Ting-Lu and Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Paldean Tauros-F makes major use of its unique typing defensively, so it only needs to Terastallize for situational win conditions.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type makes Paldean Tauros-F far less vulnerable to Rotom-W and Rotom-W, in addition to dealing with Focus Sash Breloom.

  • Fairy: When paired with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type means Dragonite will no longer wall Paldean Tauros-F without Teratsallizing itself.

Items

  • Eject Pack: With Close Combat, this will give Paldean Tauros-F a powerful, one-time use pivot option.

  • Life Orb: This high value item can be tough to slot in, but the increased power makes sweeping with a Speed boost much easier.

  • Mirror Herb: Mirror Herb punishes setup sweepers even more effectively and pairs especially well with Intimidate.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With an Assault Vest, Paldean Tauros-F finds itself a niche checking Choice Band Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, and Iron Moth.

  • Raging Bull Despite Flare Blitz having more power, Raging Bull is Paldean Tauros-F's preferred STAB move as a result of its ability to break Aurora Veil, Reflect, and Light Screen, as well as the lack of recoil associated with the move.

  • Iron Head vs Stone Edge Iron Head is used because of its ability to hit foes that can Terastallize into Fairy-types, such as Dondozo and some Dragonite; it also provides a midground against Rock-types such as Garganacl and Tyranittar. It also is Paldean Tauros-F's best shot at OHKOing Flutter Mane without Terastallizing. However, Stone Edge can be used in lieu of it, as it is Tauros-F's best chance of defeating Iron Moth.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type allows Paldean Tauros-F to be immune to Acid Spray attempts from Iron Moth, as well as boosting the power of Iron Head. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane more easily, as Flutter Mane would otherwise need lots of defensive investment to survive it.

  • Grass: Tera Grass prevents Azumarill's Liquidation from OHKOing Paldean Tauros-F, as well as providing a boost to Trailblaze.

  • Fire: Like Tera Steel, Tera Fire provides useful resistance to Fairy, notably Flutter Mane. It also allows Paldean Tauros-B to OHKO Flutter Mane that don't invest in bulk with Raging Bull.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 12 Atk / 76 Def / 36 SpD / 140 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread allows Paldean Tauros-B to defeat Flutter Mane with Trailblaze into Raging Bull. The Defense EVs allow it to beat Choice Band Chien-Pao after Intimidate one-on-one. The Speed investment allows Paldean Tauros-B to outpace Flutter Mane after Trailblaze.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This set is currently in copyediting. It can be found here.

Gyarados.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Rocky Helmet
sets.description:
• Gyarados utilizes its unique typing alongside Rocky Helmet to cushion physical sweepers such as Scizor, Great Tusk and Palafin.

  • Taunt: Taunt forces foes such as Corviknight and Dondozo to attack Gyarados, constraining them to take Rocky Helmet chip while often dealing minimal damage themselves.

  • Waterfall versus Iron Head: Waterfall provides Gyarados with a reliable STAB move, but Iron Head works better with Thunder Wave thanks to its higher flinch chance. They can be run together, though usually at the cost of overall coverage.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake checks several common Gyarados switch-ins, such as Iron Hands and Magnezone.

  • Ice Fang: Ice Fang hits bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite that otherwise can withstand attacks from Gyarados.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave combined with flinch moves like Waterfall and Iron Head can shut down foes for several turns at a time. It can also catch foes switching into Gyarados, though keep in mind that many prominent Gyarados checks are naturally immune.

  • EV Spread: This spread allows Gyarados to survive two unboosted Moonblasts from Flutter Mane and minimizes Stealth Rock chip. The Speed investment outspeeds 4 Speed Rotom formes and, when using Thunder Wave, outspeeds paralyzed Speed-boosting nature Dragapult.

Other Options

  • Dragon Dance: Rocky Helmet sets can still opt to utilize Dragon Dance for more offensive presence, but this usually involves cutting bulk to invest in Attack and Speed.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Gyarados has uses for Terastallization, losing its unique defensive typing jeopardizes its Rocky Helmet niche and makes it much harder to check its key targets. Terastallization must be timed properly if Gyarados is to get proper value out of it.

  • Steel: Tera Steel powers up Iron Head to more serviceable levels and makes it easier to OHKO bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Ground: Tera Ground prevents Gyarados from getting dismantled by its 4x Electric-type weakness and provides a sizable power boost to Earthquake.

Ditto.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
• Ditto is widely hailed as the best revenge killer and finds a small niche with a Choice Scarf.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Ditto rarely needs to Terastallize unless it is being threatened by Dragon Dance Dragonite's Extreme Speed at +3.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Ditto immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed, preventing it from defeating Ditto after three Dragon Dances.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: The safest option, Choice Scarf guarantees that Ditto will always outspeed the foe unless said foe is holding a Choice Scarf.
  • Focus Sash: A high-risk yet high-reward option, Focus Sash allows Ditto to switch moves at the cost of being nullified by entry hazards. However, it should be noted that Imposter doesn't copy Protosynthesis or Quark Drive boosts, making Focus Sash a lot less niche, as it allows Ditto to beat foes such as Flutter Mane more consistently assuming the field is clear of hazards.

EV Spreads

  • Effort Values: The given EVs maximize Ditto's bulk in the rare case of a mirror matchup.
  • Individual Values: 0 Speed IVs and a minus Speed nature is key to beating opposing Ditto, as the Ditto that moves last on the fourth turn will win the mirror.

Dragonite.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Extreme Killernite
sets.description:
• With Tera Normal, Dragonite can do its best impression of Arceus, with a powerful Extreme Speed that makes Dragonite a great revenge killer, and even a sweeper if using Dragon Dance!

  • Earthquake: Earthquake offers the best coverage against the widest variety of Steel-types, with Heatran being a major target. Just note that some Levitate Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Air Balloon Gholdengo can completely wall Dragonite.

  • Encore: Encore can be tricky to fit in on Dragonite, since giving up Roost greatly harms Dragonite's lasting power, and giving up Dragon Dance makes sweeping much more difficult. However, the amount of match-ups it lets Dragonite win against passive Pokemon, and the amount of switch-ins it gives it, make it a worthy move to consider regardless.

  • Tera Dependency - High: This set benefits immensely from the ability to Terastallize to both boost Extreme Speed's power while also removing Dragon type weaknesses. However, care should be taken on the timing of Terastallization depending on the matchup, as Dragonite more effectively checks several prominent threats, such as Urshifu-R and Heatran, with its base typing.

Other Options

  • Fire Punch: Fire Punch gets around Dragonite's issue with Tera Steel Levitate Pokemon such as Rotom-W, but it makes Heatran a big issue.

  • Waterfall: Waterfall acts as decent role compression, allowing Dragonite to hit Heatran and Levitating Steel-types, but it's coverage is nowhere near as good as Earthquake otherwise.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Stealth Rock is commonly set up specifically to break Dragonite's Multiscale, so Heavy-Duty Boots are a good way to always preserve Dragonite's ability to set up and revenge kill.

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry gives Dragonite more set up opportunities against status moves and pairs particularly well with Outrage to cure confusion.

  • Leftovers: On more defensive or Encore based Dragonite, the residual recovery of Leftovers adds up.

  • Rocky Helmet: For more defensive EV spreads, Rocky Helmet lets Dragonite play more passively against physical threats.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish Going fully defensive means Dragonite won't sweep nearly as easily, but Dragonite is still capable of being an effective defensive Pokemon even after Terastallization.

  • 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 Spe with Impish or 156 HP / 252 Atk / 100 Spe with Adamant: These EV spreads outspeeds Jolly Ursaluna, who while not common, can seriously threaten to break past Dragonite with Guts boosted Facade.

  • 20 HP / 252 Atk / 236 Spe with Jolly: This EV spread is the minimum amount of Speed needed to outspeed Dragapult and Flutter Mane after Dragon Dance, the fastest two Pokemon immune to Extreme Speed. Outspeeding Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao can also be useful since both are known to sometimes use Tera Ghost for Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Choice Band makes Dragonite both an effective late-game cleaner and revenge killer with Extreme Speed, and a powerful wall-breaker against foes such as Dondozo and Skeledirge.

  • Outrage: Outrage is strong enough to potentially 2HKO Impish Dondozo after Stealth Rock damage, though it leaves Dragonite very vulnerable to getting revenge killed.

  • Iron Head: While Steel-type coverage isn't incredible, it allows Dragonote to punish Levitate Pokemon that sometimes Terastallize into Fairy-types, such as Cresselia and Rotom-W.

  • Fire Punch: Fire Punch covers Steel-types that are immune to Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, Air Balloon Gholdengo, and Tera Steel Rotom-W.

  • Special Attack IV of 17 or lower: If using Tera Flying, a Special Attack IV of 17 or lower is needed to prevent Tera Blast from flipping to a Special Attack after being hit by Flutter Mane's Charm.

Other Options

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet works as a secondary priority move to pick off Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, and Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: This Dragonite will usually want to Terastallize to either increase its revenge killing or wall-breaking capabilities, but Choice Band's power doesn't make this strictly necessary.

  • Normal: Tera Normal massively boosts Dragonite's revenge killing potential with Extreme Speed.

  • Flying: With Tera Blast, Tera Flying is a strong wallbreaking option that lets Dragonite potentially OHKO Wo-Chien before it Terastallizes and 2HKO bulky Pokemon such Cresselia and specially defensive Ting-Lu. It also lets Dragonite demolish offensive Urshifu without the need for Outrage.

sets.name: Defensive Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Dragonite's good bulk gives it plenty of chances to set up Dragon Dance, while still providing a solid defensive backbone.

  • Encore: Encore makes setting up on slower defensive foes such as Corviknight fairly easy, though the lack of coverage makes Terastallizing far more important.

  • Earthquake: This Dragonite's most common Tera types are fairly vulnerable to Heatran, making Earthquake a good coverage move.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner deals massive damage to Landorus-T and other Flying-types, making it a reasonable coverage option to consider if using a Tera type that can deal with Heatran, like Water or Electric.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High / Almost Required: This Dragonite lacks a STAB attack without Terastallization, making it highly recommended. If using Tera Flying with Tera Blast as the only attack, this set will need Terastallization to function.

  • Flying: With Tera Blast, Tera Flying gives Dragonite a solid mono-attacking option and defensive typing in one, at the cost of almost always needing to Terastallize to function.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Dragonite an excellent mono-attacking Tera Blast that gives it an advantage over other Dragon-types.

  • Steel: Tera Steel covers Dragonite's former weaknesses very well, and can still work somewhat well even if not Terastallized thanks to Iron Head, though note it makes this Dragonite much more vulnerable to Urshifu.

  • Water: Tera Water is among this Dragonite's few Tera types that hits Heatran hard, making Waterfall a particularly attractive option. Just note that Water Absorb Clodsire will completely wall this set if not using extra coverage.

  • Electric: Though this requires extra coverage to be viable Tera Electric gives Dragonite only a single weakness to Ground-type attacks, and has excellent coverage with Ice Spinner.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet lets Dragonite play more passively thanks to the chip damage.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Preserving Multiscale even when Stealth Rock is set up can help Dragonite survive attacks in emergencies.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's passive healing gives Dragonite a better matchup against passive foes it can Encore.

  • Covert Cloak: With Covert Cloak, Dragonite becomes a very solid check to Garganacl, as well as no longer fearing Acid Spray or flinches.

  • Weakness Policy: Since Multiscale makes Dragonite very difficult to OHKO, Weakness Policy is a viable option to turn the tables on foes targeting Dragonite's weaknesses.

EV Spreads And Dragon Dance Speed Tiers

  • 252 HP / 188 Defense / 76 Spe with Impish: This EV spread outspeeds up to Urshifu after one Dragon Dance, and Dragapult after two Dragon Dances.

  • 252 HP / 148 Defense / 108 Speed with Impish: This spread outspeeds Garchomp, Thundurus-T, and Chi-Yu after Dragon Dance, all of which are threats that can easily revenge kill Dragonite once Multiscale is broken.

  • 252 HP / 20 Def / 236 Spe with Jolly: This is the minimum Speed needed to outspeed Jolly Dragapult after a boost, and it also outspeeds Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Dragon Tail Phazer
sets.description:
• With Multiscale's incredible bulk potential and Dragon Tail bypassing Taunt, Dragonite is a unique and very effective phazer that massively ups the danger of entry hazards!

  • Entry Hazard Teammates: For this Dragonite to be at its most effective, you'll need some partners to at least set up Stealth Rock. Ting-Lu and Garchomp stand out for being particularly bulky options that can even set up Spikes, but other options include Annihilape, Clodsire, Landorus-T, and Kleavor.

  • Earthquake versus Iron Head: Earthquake is the most wide-reaching coverage move, ensuring good damage against Steel-types like Heatran and Hisuian Goodra. Iron Head is worth considering as it prevents Dragonite from being walled by Tera Fairy Rotom-W and has good damage output against Fairy-types like Flutter Mane and Mimikyu.

  • Substitute versus Encore: Substitute is a fantastic option against Pokemon with status moves that threaten Dragonite's phazing cycles, such as Garganacl, Wo-Chien, and Clodsire. Encore won't do as well against these threats but does punish opposing foes carrying Substitute that can be a problem for Dragon Tail along with slower foes that use status moves in general such as Dondozo and Ursaluna. Encore can even be used over extra coverage if teammates can deal with Fairy-types.

  • Extreme Speed versus Aqua Jet: Extreme Speed's ability to pick off threats is useful, even on defensive variants of this set. Despite being half as powerful, Aqua Jet is still worth considering for its ability to pick off weakened Flutter Mane, which can be difficult for this set to handle due to its power when Multiscale isn't in play.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragonite's defensive typing can be quite helpful against foes like Urshifu-R and Chi-Yu, but some of the huge exploitable weakness to Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane will require Terastallization to cover.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dragon immunity gels well with Dragonite and is a great defensive typing in general against foes like Chien-Pao and Urshifu.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is not only an incredible defensive typing that covers much of Dragonite's former weaknesses, but the power boost it provides to Iron Head lets it OHKO all but the most bulky Flutter Mane.

  • Water: Tera Water's Ice and Fire resistance makes it a great pick against Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Heatran and is among the best defensive types in general. The boost to Aqua Jet can also be helpful for picking off threats, though it won't be as powerful as Extreme Speed.

  • Normal: Tera Normal isn't that incredible defensively, but it can be worth it for boosting Extreme Speed's power, letting offensive EV spreads 2HKO Chien-Pao with it.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a niche option that lets Dragonite absorb Toxic Spikes and gain a Toxic immunity without being weak to Fighting- and Fire-type attacks like Tera Steel is.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a high value item, but it's worth using on Dragonite if using Substitute, as it gives Dragonite a serious chance of passively gaining Multiscale's effect back.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet allows Dragonite to play more passively, punishing Pokemon that rely on contact moves like Choice Item Urshifu-R and Annihilape.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Heavy-Duty Boots' Stealth Rock immunity makes Multiscale more flexible, especially if Dragon Tail brings in a threat Dragonite isn't equipped to handle.

  • Safety Goggles: With Dragonite often moving last with Dragon Tail, it's especially vulnerable to Spore from Breloom, Amoonguss, and Brute Bonnet, so Safety Goggles can be a good pick if Substitute isn't a good fit.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 Spe with Impish: This spread outspeeds Jolly Ursaluna, who while not common, can seriously threaten to blast past Dragonite with Facade.

  • 252 HP / 76 Def / 180 Spe with Impish: This spread gives up quite a bit of bulk in exchange for outspeeding Adamant Breloom, while still often mantaining a Substitute against Garganacl's Salt Cure.

  • 252 HP / 124 Atk / 108 Def / 4 SpD / 20 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread is optimized for use with Earthquake and Aqua Jet, allowing Dragonite to 2HKO 4 Defense Flutter Mane with that combination of moves without needing to Terastallize. Only Modest Tera Fairy Flutter Mane will have a chance to OHKO through Multiscale.

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This EV spread is a far more offensive approach, mainly for use with Extreme Speed to pick off threats more effectively.

sets.name: Encore Trapper
sets.description:
• Due to Dragonite's offensive presence and high bulk, many opponents choose to either check it defensively or set up against it to break through Roost + Multiscale. Against either option, Encore can turn Dragonite practically invincible allowing it to reside on the field indefinitely in most cases.

  • Fire Spin: This allows Dragonite to defeat almost any Pokemon universally by simply making full use of its longevity. Trapping an Encore locked Pokemon in the field is also highly valuable. Fire Spin is used instead of Wrap because it affects Ghost-types and doesn't trigger chip damage from Rough Skin and Rocky Helmet.

  • Earthquake versus Waterfall: Earthquake prevents Dragonite from being entirely passive against Heatran, Flutter Mane, and Clodsire. Waterfall isn't as as great against Steel-types, but still covers Heatran and Flying-types like Landorus-T and Thundurus-T.

Other Options

  • Iron Head: Even with minimal Attack investment, Iron Head has a serious shot of OHKOing offensive Flutter Mane, and it gives Dragonite a decent STAB move if using Tera Steel. Just note that it makes Dragonite very vulnerable to Heatran.

  • Draco Meteor: With a Bold Nature, Draco Meteor is a powerful move that can catch opposing Dragon-types off-guard and deal big damage to Dondozo and Urshifu, though its severely walled by Heatran.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Dragonite's typing does have some fairly exploitable weaknesses that can harm its defensive capability, but an immunity to Toxic Spikes and useful resistances to common attack types such as Ground, Fire, and Fighting mean that Terastallization is not always the right play.

  • Fairy: Due to Dragonite’'s low Speed compared to other Dragon-types, Tera Fairy is a great response against them. This also retains its advantage against Urshifu formes.

  • Steel: Tera Steel massively improves Dragonite's matchups against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, at the cost of being even more vulnerable to Salt Cure and Urshifu formes.

  • Water: Tera Water adds a resistance to Ice without losing Dragonite's innate Fire-type resistance, which is helpful against Chien-Pao and Urshifu-R.

  • Poison: The niche Tera Poison gives Dragonite a way to remove its common weaknesses without being vulnerable to Toxic Spikes, while still resisting Fighting unlike Tera Steel.

Alternate EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 Spe with Impish: This EV spread outspeeds Jolly Ursaluna, who can threaten to wallbreak Dragonite before it can Encore Earthquake or Headlong Rush otherwise.

Items

  • Leftovers versus Heavy-Duty Boots Generally, Leftovers preserves Dragonite’'s longevity best, as it cancels out the damage from Sandstorm and makes timer stall easier. However, the increased usage of entry hazard setters in response to Dragonite makes Heavy-Duty Boots a strong option.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet makes it easier for Dragonite to defeat Pokemon such as opposing Dragonite, Kingambit, and Meowscarada, and its residual damage can be used to execute a win condition.

  • Covert Cloak: With Covert Cloak, this Dragonite becomes a very effective check to Garganacl, in addition to no longer being vulnerable to flinches from Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash while Terastallizing.

sets.name: Paraflinch
sets.description:
• Paraflinch Dragonite is a defensively oriented Dragonite set that takes full advantage of Terastallization and the element of surprise to cripple and downright defeat numerous Pokemon. Multiscale allows Dragonite to paralyze its foes relatively safely, becoming a massive nuisance for unprepared opponents.

  • Air Slash vs. Iron Head: Air Slash is a more practical move for this set, as it can cover a wider range of Pokemon for at least neutral damage. Air Slash also does not trigger Rocky Helmet and is naturally boosted by Dragonite's STAB. The Iron Head variant of Paraflinch, however, gives Dragonite an easier time against a number of common threats such as Flutter Mane, at the cost of only defeating Heatran that are Terastallized.

  • Encore vs. Substitute: Encore will allow Dragonite to effectively check a wider variety of Pokemon such as Ursaluna by locking them into an unfavorable move, giving it a free opportunity to land Thunder Wave on your opponent's switch-in on the following turn. Substitute, on the other hand, will give Dragonite a much easier time dealing with defensive Pokemon that rely on status inflictions such as Wo-Chien and Dondozo.

Other Options

  • Waterfall: Waterfall can be a viable option. However, the move is less reliable for the application of this set, as its chance to flinch is 20% as opposed to Air Slash and Iron Head's 30%. It does deal more damage to common Electric-types like Thundurus-T though.

Tera Types

  • Water: Tera Water provides Dragonite with the much-needed defensive versatility to paralyze and wall common threats, such as Chien-Pao and Azumarill. Water is an excellent defensive type in general with its only weaknesses being Electric and Grass.

  • Steel: Steel is a great defensive type that provides resistance to Fairy-type attacks, such as Moon Blast from Flutter Mane. If using the physical set, Tera Steel also provides a significant boost to the damage of Iron Head.

EV and IV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 212 Def / 52 Spe: 52 Speed EVs are the minimum Speed requirement to outspeed paralyzed Dragapult.

  • 252 HP / 140 Def / 116 Spe: This is the minimum requirement to outspeed paralyzed Modest Choice Scarf Chi-Yu.

  • 0 Attack IVs: If using Air Slash, 0 Attack IVs are highly recommended for having a high chance of retaining Substitute against STAB Foul Play users such as Wo-Chien and Umbreon.

sets.name: Double Priority Lure
sets.description:
• With Flying-type Tera Blast OHKOing physically frail and Flying-weak Pokemon such as Flutter Mane and Urshifu-R, this set is effective at fooling opponents into thinking that it's Choice Band Dragonite.

  • Aqua Jet: It may seem redundant with Extreme Speed, but Aqua Jet is a key move for picking off weakened Ghost-types, such as Flutter Mane, and surprising Focus Sash Pokemon that might use Tera Ghost to avoid being sniped by Extreme Speed, such as Iron Bundle. This can also work against Chien-Pao, but Icicle Crash's flinch chance makes this rather risky.

  • Earthquake versus Low Kick: Earthquake is the preferred coverage move for OHKOing Heatran, a common response when thinking Dragonite is locked into Tera Blast. Low Kick trades that OHKO from full health for revenge killing opposing Tera Normal Dragonite and dealing massive damage to Ting-Lu.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: Adamant is the best nature for needing less chip damage to revenge kill weakened targets with priority attacks, but Jolly can make sense if outspeeding foes like Jolly Breloom, Modest Gholdengo, and Adamant Baxcalibur is appealing.

  • Tera Dependency - Almost Required: This set is highly reliant on using Tera Blast as a luring tool, so Terastallization should be a top priority for Dragonite.

Items

  • Sharp Beak: Sharp Beak gives Dragonite the most offensive presence with the fewest drawbacks, giving Flying-type Tera Blast just enough of a boost to 3HKO Dondozo. This heavily pressures it to use Rest, or possibly Protect for Leftovers variants. In the latter case, Dragonite can switch to maintain offensive momentum.

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest vastly improves Dragonite's matchup against Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane, especially if Multiscale's protection has been lost.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Heavy-Duty Boots means Stealth Rock will no longer remove this set's ability to trade blows with powerful threats.

Azumarill.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With a fantastic typing that checks key threats like Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu and a good STAB priority attack, Azumarill is a common choice for a team's bulky Water-type.

  • Superpower: Superpower often forces Azumarill to switch out, but it deals massive damage to the important Iron Bundle.

Other Options

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner lets Azumarill deal serious damage to Water Absorb Clodsire and does more against Dragonite before it Terastallizes.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Azumarill has a fantastic typing that it normally wants to keep, but it being rather weak to Iron Bundle is a major issue that can force it to Terastallize.

  • Water: Tera Water not only makes it easier to clean weakened teams with Aqua Jet, but it also lets Choice Band Azumarill OHKO uninvested Flutter Mane with Aqua Jet.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Assault Vest Azumarill a much better matchup against Iron Bundle, no longer being weak to Freeze-Dry and OHKOing it after Stealth Rock damage with Play Rough.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Azumarill a vital immunity to Will-O-Wisp, as well as letting it deal massive damage to Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Azumarill deal massive damage to Dondozo, Toxapex, and Corviknight, plus it OHKOes Iron Bundle.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Azumarill beat Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Rotom-W.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets Azumarill act as a decent Chi-Yu check, with only +2 Life Orb Overheat even coming close to OHKOing.

  • Choice Band: The big power boost from Choice Band gives Azumarill an 81.3% chance to OHKO Rotom-H with Aqua Jet, and it lets it pick off major foes such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk more easily.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
• Azumarill's excellent typing and access to priority Aqua Jet make it one of the best Belly Drum users in the metagame.

  • Liquidation: Liquidation remains a strong Water-type STAB move and makes Azumarill more usable in matchups where Belly Drum can't be used. When boosted by Belly Drum, Liquidation is fully capable of punching through bulky Steel-types—like Corviknight—that Play Rough can't.

  • Encore: Encore can create an opening to use Belly Drum against slower, more passive foes, such as Ting-Lu, though the decreased offensive coverage can hurt in the long run.

  • Belly Drum Usage: While finding a safe opportunity to use Belly Drum can be tough, Azumarill can cushion hits well from and set up on popular sweepers like Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, given that they don't have a Tera type that counters Azumarill. Azumarill can still hit hard even without Belly Drum, so don't force it if the situation looks too dangerous.

  • EV Spread : 244 HP EVs are used to give Azumarill an even HP number, guaranteeing that Sitrus Berry activates after Belly Drum. The extra EVs are put into Speed to prevent Speed ties with opposing 4 Speed Azumarill.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Belly Drum is inherently risky; smart Tera usage can cushion an attack during setup or provide a stronger coverage option when Belly Drum simply isn't viable to use.

  • Water: Tera Water combined with Belly Drum gives Aqua Jet nightmarish power. After Stealth Rock chip, it can even OHKO Iron Bundle!

  • Fire: Tera Fire blocks Will-O-Wisp, and the Tera Blast coverage can hit Steel-types like Scizor and Corviknight hard even without Belly Drum.

  • Grass: Tera Grass turns both Grass- and Electric-type weaknesses into resistances, and when combined with Tera Blast, it makes dealing with Unaware Dondozo and Rotom-W much easier. It can also be used to block Spore and set up Belly Drum for free, but this must be done with discretion, as Spore users like Loaded Dice Breloom may just attack and leave Azumarill heavily wounded after Belly Drum.

  • Electric: Tera Electric with Tera Blast is Azumarill's best option to beat Toxapex, and it still deals big damage to Unaware Dondozo and Corviknight.

sets.name: Substitute + Encore
sets.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Umbreon.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Wish Tank
sets.description:
• Umbreon’s high bulk allows it tank a slew of offensive Pokemon. In particular, it matches up extremely well against Dragapult. A naturally high bulk alongside excellent utility moves means Umbreon can generate tempo while surviving even surprise Tera-boosted attacks.

  • Foul Play: In such a physically leaning format, Foul Play is a strong reliable move to chip the opponent’s Pokemon. In particular, it punishes Swords Dance from Lum Berry Kingambit. Protect also scouts for U-turn and Tera.

  • Wish and Protect: Wish + Protect provides excellent recovery, and with Leftovers's animation as well, is great at stalling out the timer and can also keep teammates healthy.

  • Yawn: Yawn's ability to force switches generates extra Leftovers recovery and generates momentum for its teammates.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave has excellent synergy with Wish. If the opponent’s Pokemon is unable to attack on the turn Umbreon uses Wish, Umbreon can easily pass the Wish to a teammate.

  • Taunt: Umbreon can Taunt opposing walls and deny their recovery; with foes such as Hippowdon and Corviknight being especially vulnerable.

Tera Types

  • Poison: Tera Poison resists Fighting, Bug, and Fairy and provides an immunity to Toxic.

  • Steel: Tera Steel resists Bug and Fairy, is immune to Toxic, and has a decent matchup against Kingambit and Flutter Mane.

  • Fairy: In a heavily Dragon-centric metagame, Tera Fairy on defensive Pokemon is highly valuable.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Bold: This spread allows Umbreon to tank a majority of the heavily physical metagame.

  • 172 HP / 252 Def / 60 SpD / 20 Spe with Bold: If running Taunt, 20 Speed EVs outpace Skeledirge and Corviknight while retaining all-around bulk.

Abilities

  • Inner Focus: Inner Focus avoids flinches from Kingambit and Hydreigon, making it a more reliable check.

  • Synchronize: Synchronize punishes attempts to burn Umbreon.

Slowking-Galar.overview: This Pokemon is a new addition to the Regulation D format! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

sets.name: AV Tank
sets.description:
• Thanks to its great Special Defense, unique typing, and Regenerator, Galarian Slowking functions well as an Assault Vest user.

  • Assault Vest: While Galarian Slowking has access to Slack Off, Regenerator can provide some recovery if needed, and an Assault Vest increases its Special Defense to titanic levels.

  • Future Sight: Future Sight is Galarian Slowking's strongest move and provides phenomenal field pressure due to hitting two turns after it's used, allowing for combinations with another teammate's move.

  • Eerie Spell versus Psychic: Psychic offers more PP, while Eerie Spell depletes the PP of the last move used by the opponent by 3, which can be useful when fighting against opponents with low PP moves, such as recovery moves.

  • Acid Spray: Acid Spray makes Galarian Slowking much less passive and prone to setup against opponents that aren't immune, and the Special Defense drops can be deadly when combined with Future Sight, alongside making Galarian Slowking harder to check defensively.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake is Galarian Slowking's best option against Heatran and Hisuian Goodra, even when using a Calm nature.

  • Ice Beam: Ice Beam allows Galarian Slowking to hit Ground-types such as Ting-Lu, Landorus-T, and Ursaluna for more damage than its Psychic STAB moves.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower hits other Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Corviknight.

  • Calm versus Sassy: If using Earthquake, a Sassy Nature lets Galarian Slowking have a shot at 3HKOing max HP Hisuian Goodra, though at the risk of getting outsped by Amoonguss. A Calm Nature has better odds at Speed tying or outspeeding Amoonguss.

Other Options

  • Psyshock: Despite having little synergy with Acid Spray, Psyshock hits Flutter Mane and Clodsire the hardest before factoring Special Defense drops.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Calm / Sassy: This EV spread focuses on Galarian Slowking's ability to take special attacks to the point where powerful super effective hits such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball only has a chance of 2HKOing it 75.4% of the time.

  • 252 HP / 28 Def / 84 SpA / 140 SpD / 4 Spe with Modest / Quiet: This spread survives Jolly Choice Band Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes while OHKOing it with Eerie Spell.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Galarian Slowking is perfectly able to function without Terastallization, but it can boost its defensive profile.

  • Normal: A well-timed Tera Normal can severely hamper opponents hoping to take down Galarian Slowking with Ghost-type moves.

  • Poison: Tera Poison removes Galarian Slowking's weaknesses to Ghost-, and Dark-type attacks, and it boosts Sludge Bomb and Acid Spray's power.

  • Grass: Tera Grass turns Galarian Slowking's Ground weakness into a resistance, can help it take Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes better, and provides a handy immunity to Spore.

Scizor.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Scizor's incredible power and good typing make it one of the premier priority sweepers, being able to sweep through huge threats such as Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao!

  • U-turn: While pivoting doesn't gel well with sweeping, it makes this kind of Scizor very adaptable, and is especially effective at getting away from Pokemon that threaten with residual damage, like Wo-Chien and Garganacl.

  • Thief: Thief is Scizor's most reliable way of getting past Gholdengo.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat lets Scizor smash through Chi-Yu and Ting-Lu, and 2HKO Corviknight after a boost.

Other Options

  • Trailblaze: Trailblaze will 2HKO even the bulkiest Rotom-W without a boost and deal good chip damage to Dondozo. The Speed boost also comes in handy considering how crowded Scizor's Speed tier is.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium / Low: Terastallization works very well at shutting down common methods of revenge killing or walling Scizor, but its typing is good enough to function without Terastallization. If using U-turn, Scizor can focus on pivoting in some matches, making Terastallization even less needed.

  • Water: Tera Water lets Scizor ambush Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Heatran with a resistance and is especially handy against Fire-types when using Tera Blast.

  • Steel: Boosting Bullet Punch is Scizor's best ticket for revenge killing and late-game sweeping, and it retains its Flying-type resistance into powerful Tera Flying Choice Band users like Dragonite and Landorus-T.

  • Dark: Tera Dark can cushion Shadow Ball from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, giving it an extra turn to set up or hit back with Tera-boosted Thief.

  • Electric: Tera Electric is Scizor's best shot of breaking past Toxapex and Urshifu-R with Tera Blast, and it does good chip damage to Dondozo.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry and 244 HP EVs: Sitrus Berry trades late-game sweeping power for new setup opportunities, such as avoiding a 2HKO from Modest Gholdengo that lack Choice Specs and a good chance of avoiding a 2HKO from Timid Rotom-W's Hydro Pump. It also has good synergy with Thief, allowing Scizor to steal important items such as Leftovers from Dondozo. Make sure to run 244 Speed EVs to gain an even HP number, letting Sitrus activate after getting hit by Ruination once.

  • Rocky Helmet: Best used with U-turn, Rocky Helmet transforms this Scizor into a good bulky pivot that has the surprising option to sweep late-game.

  • Life Orb: While Life Orb does compromise Scizor's bulk, it's worth it for being able to OHKO Iron Bundle with a boosted Bullet Punch, and has a good shot of OHKOing physically defensive Ting-Lu with a boosted Close Combat as well.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 28 Atk / 204 Def / 20 SpD / 4 Spe with Adamant: This bulky spread avoids the OHKO from Adamant Tera Ghost Life Orb Mimikyu's +2 Shadow Claw. When used with Sitrus Berry, it also avoids the 2HKO from Modest Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

  • 236 HP / 228 Atk / 20 Def / 20 SpD / 4 Spe with Adamant: This spread gives Scizor enough bulk to survive Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao's Throat Chop, and less residual damage if using U-turn. It also avoids a 2HKO from Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast. With Sitrus Berry, Modest Gholdengo's Shadow Ball is also no longer a 2HKO.

  • 228 HP / 124 Atk / 156 SpD with Adamant: This Sitrus Berry optimized spread avoids a 2HKO from Jolly Chien-Pao's Crunch, Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump, and Modest Choice Specs Tera Fairy Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def with Impish: This defensive spread is best used with U-turn and Rocky Helmet, making Scizor function more like a bulky pivot that can sweep late-game.

Minor Optimizations

  • Slow U-turn: When running U-turn, Scizor can drop the Speed investment from any spread and run a Speed IV of 27 to underspeed opposing Scizor and the rare Chesnaught.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Thanks to its high Attack, great defensive typing and solid bulk, Scizor is an effective bulky pivot that can also punish faster foes with Technician-boosted Bullet Punch, such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Baxcalibur.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat is Scizor's best option to hit opposing Chi-Yu as well as Steel types, even when using defensive EV spreads.

  • Thief Thief is a great option for hitting Gholdengo hard thanks to the Technician boost.

Other Options

  • Aerial Ace This is an option over Thief to hit Fighting types like Urshifu-R, Annihilape, and Breloom, but leaves you vulnerable to Gholdengo.

  • Trailblaze: Besides gaining a useful Speed boost, Trailblaze does good damage to Urshifu-R and Rotom-W.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Terastallization can be quite helpful in either cleaning teams or preparing against Scizor's classic Fire-type issues, the power of its priority and pivoting don't make it needed for it to function consistently.

  • Steel: Choice Band Scizor is a fairly good user of Terastallization, with Tera Steel boosting Bullet Punch to terrifying levels. Tera Steel also softens Scizor's weakness to Fire, letting it avoid the OHKO from attacks like Flutter Mane's Mystical Fire.

  • Water: Tera Water turns its Fire weakness into a resistance, giving Scizor a fighting chance against dangerous Fire-types such as Heatran and Chi-Yu.

  • Dark: Tera Dark works as a single turn surprise to soften Ghost-type attacks from the likes of Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. The power boost to Thief also helps Scizor take a much bigger chunk out of Gholdengo.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band lets Scizor function as a scary late-game cleaner, especially with Tera Steel-boosted Bullet Punch. The high damage output also helps Scizor to break down walls for its teammates.

  • Assault Vest: While much less immediately threatening than Choice Band, Assault Vest lets Scizor more comfortably switch into stray special attacks like Gholdengo's and Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball or Rotom-W's Volt Switch, improving its longevity.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet is perfect for more defensive Scizor, letting it continually switch into weaker physical attacks and wear down the team with U-turn and residual damage.

EV Spreads

  • 236 HP / 68 Atk / 204 Def with Adamant: This spread avoids a OHKO from Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao, is not 2HKOed by Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Moonblast, and reduces the amount of residual damage Scizor receives thanks to the HP stat being 1 lower than divisible by 16.

  • 236 HP / 68 Atk / 204 Def with Adamant: This bulky spread lets Scizor survive +2 Life Orb Adamant Tera Ghost Mimikyu's Shadow Claw.

  • 252 HP / 92 Atk / 164 SpD with Adamant: This spread is meant to be used with Assault Vest, letting Scizor almost always avoid a 2HKO from Modest Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball. It also maintains enough Attack investment to always OHKO uninvested Chien-Pao after Stealth Rock chip.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Def with Impish: Defensive Scizor might seem strange, but when paired with Rocky Helmet, it becomes an effective pivot that can survive extreme attacks: it avoids the OHKO from Choice Band Tera Dark Chien-Pao's Crunch as well as the 2HKO from Adamant Landorus-T's Earthquake. Just note that this will make Scizor focus more on pivoting than revenge killing with Bullet Punch.

Minor Optimizations

  • Slow U-turn: Scizor already has a very slow U-turn, but Scizor can drop the Speed investment from any spread and run a Speed IV of 27 to underspeed opposing Scizor and the rare Chesnaught.

Blissey.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Calm Mind Support
sets.description:
• The old reliable special wall is still viable, but it now takes a more active role through the use of Calm Mind.

  • Shadow Ball: Ghost-types like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Swords Dance Mimikyu are still common options used against Blissey. This makes Shadow Ball a consistently strong option, particularly after a couple of Calm Mind boosts.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast is a very flexible attacking option, giving reliable STAB before Terastallizing and providing new offensive coverage thereafter.

  • Fling with Flame Orb: This is a surprising option to burn common Blissey switch-ins like Great Tusk, though failing to use it right away will force switching out to get rid of the burn. Fling also gets rid of Choice items from Trick users.

  • Stealth Rock: Stealth Rock remains a trusty support move for Blissey, punishing teams that are forced to switch around Blissey and its teammates.

Other Options

  • Fling with Toxic Orb: This is as close as it gets to Blissey regaining Toxic, though getting badly poisoned is devestating if Blissey is the last Pokemon around, making it a risky option.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Blissey is known for shrugging off big special hits with ease. However, its presence at team preview often attracts hard counters, and Tera is one way of dealing with that.

  • Dark: Dark Tera ruins Espathra's attempts to break through Blissey with Stored Power, at least forcing a Calm Mind war instead of a total loss. Blocking the occasional Psyshock from foes like Nasty Plot Gholdengo is also a plus.

  • Ghost: The Fighting-type immunity comes in handy for Blissey and prevents it from being trapped, though it does become more vulnerable to Gholdengo.

  • Fire: Tera Fire puts the brakes on Choice Specs Tera Fire Chi-Yu’s wallbreaking parade, ruining its ability to reliably 2HKO Blissey.

  • Flying: With the Flying Tera type, Blissey gains a handy resistance to Fighting and no longer has to worry about Fissure from Dondozo.

Items

  • Leftovers: As is the case with most walls, Leftovers’ passive recovery is a great supplement to Softboiled and helps Blissey be less passive itself.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak lets Blissey set up against Garganacls that lack Body Press. It also blocks flinches from Chi-Yu’s Dark Pulse as well as the Special Defense drop from Espathra’s Lumina Crash.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Def / 252 SpD with Calm or Bold: Beyond making Tera Blissey that much harder to break by foes like Espathra and Chi-Yu, going all-in on Special Defense means less frequent Softboiled uses against special attackers, especially with Leftovers.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spd with Bold: Maximizing both HP and Defense gives Blissey a little extra boost in physical bulk.

sets.name: Bulky Offense
sets.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Pelipper.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Drizzle Bird
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump versus Surf: Hydro Pump significantly weakens opponents when rain-boosted, often picking up surprise KOs. Surf is the far more reliable option.

  • Hurricane versus Roost; The choice between Hurricane and Roost is a matter of coverage versus longevity. Hurricane gives Pelipper a powerful secondary STAB move, while Roost takes advantage of its decent physical bulk, increasing its staying power. This is particularly useful in weather wars against Torkoal

Tera Types

Ground: Tera Ground gives Pelipper an immunity to Volt Switch, which is often used against it early-game. This wastes a turn for the opponent and gives Pelipper the chance to safely U-turn or deal massive damage with a rain-boosted Hydro Pump.

Grass: Tera Grass is a viable option for Rotom-W, which primarily uses Hydro Pump on lead while providing a Volt Switch resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA with Quiet: With 0 Speed IVs, this is used to underspeed uninvested Hippowdon, giving Pelipper the initial advantage in weather wars.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with Relaxed: This spread gives Pelipper a better matchup against dominant, powerful physical attackers like Choice Band Dragpault and Extreme Speed Dragonite.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest: This offensive spread can be used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight and others in that Speed tier.

Items

  • Eject Button: This extra method of pivoting makes it much easier to switch Pelipper in just for getting rain up.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs can be used to take advantage of Pelipper's powerful STAB moves.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry provides longevity on defensive sets.

sets.name: Bulky Offense
sets.description:
• Between using Trace to cancel Ruin abilities and burning foes with Will-O-Wisp, Gardevoir can overwhelm some of the meta's strongest physical sweepers.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Beyond crippling physical attackers for the remainder of the match, the passive burn damage breaks Focus Sash on Chien-Pao and Multiscale on Dragonite.

  • Psyshock versus Psychic: The choice of Psychic-type STAB comes down to what you need to hit hardest. Psyshock is the best option into Flutter Mane, Iron Moth, and Clodsire, while Psychic puts more pressure on Toxapex and many variants of Bulk Up Annihilape.

Other Options

  • Sitrus Berry versus Pinch Berry: Sitrus Berry is normally the preferred recovery item for bulky Gardevoir sets, but it is a highly sought-after item. If needed elsewhere, Gardevoir's bulk profile is strong enough that running a pinch Berry can work.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Using Tera usually improves common matchups like Flutter Mane and is certainly an option if a target is deemed high enough priority. Otherwise, Gardevor's impressive suite of defensive attributes combined with excellent STAB coverage are great as is.

  • Fire: Tera Fire’s resistances to Ice, Steel, and Fairy are all excellent, greatly improving the matchups against Flutter Mane, Scizor, and Kingambit. Tera boosted Mystical Fire will also 2HKO maximum HP Kingambit without Assault Vest.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy can patch up this set's lacking power by boosting Moonblast, and the removal of Gardevoir's Psychic typing makes dealing with opposing Ghost-types like Flutter Mane and Mimikyu more manageable.

  • Normal: Tera Normal's defensive attributes are lacking overall, but nullifying a key Ghost-type attack from the likes of Flutter Mane and Mimikyu can give an opening to deal extra damage or inflict a crucial burn.

EV Spreads

  • The spreads listed below all have an even HP stat to guarantee that Sitrus Berry activates after getting hit by Ruination. All spreads are also capable of surviving one unboosted Shadow Ball from Flutter Mane.

  • 244 HP / 244 Def / 20 Spe: Near maximum HP and Defense gives Gardevoir fantastic defensive calcs; after Sitrus Berry recovery and inflicting a turn 1 burn, Gardevoir has a strong chance of avoiding the 3HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash and Assault Vest Ting-Lu's Heavy Slam. The Speed investment outspeeds maximum Speed Adamant Kingambit.

  • 244 HP / 204 Def / 60 Spe: A little extra Speed investment lets Gardevoir outspeed defensive Gholdengo with 20 Speed EVs, but Gardevoir is much less likely to avoid the 3HKOs mentioned in the main spread.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• EV Spread: This spread allows Assault Vest Gardevoir to survive Modest Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball from full health, while outspeeding Adamant Breloom.

  • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

sets.name: Choice
sets.description: • This set does not have a full write-up yet. If you'd like to finish this, feel free to reserve it here!

Breloom.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Since it can sleep foes without restriction, Breloom is a monstrous foe that applies serious pressure at Team Preview!

  • Bulldoze: This is Breloom's best option against Gholdengo and provides valuable speed control.

  • Spore: As good as Spore is, it's well prepared for enough by threats such as Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Lum Berry that going without it can make sense.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb provides a form of speed control that can't be walled by Flying-types like Dragonite.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat lets Breloom muscle past bulkier threats more easily, such as Wo-Chien.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low / Medium: While Breloom can certainly take advantage of Terastallization, Focus Sash variants are used fairly early in the game and often don't need it. Loaded Dice Breloom, however, does like Terastallization covering up its iffy defensive typing.

  • Fire: With Tera Blast, Tera Fire provides an alternative way to get past Gholdengo, avoids getting burned by other foes, and gives bulkier Breloom a chance against Flutter Mane and Focus Sash Chien-Pao.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting is a good choice for picking off foes more easily with Mach Punch.

  • Grass: Bullet Seed's boost from Tera Grass means it will OHKO Chien-Pao through its Focus Sash if Breloom rolls at least three hits.

  • Rock: Besides boosting Rock Tomb's damage output, Tera Rock prevents Sandstorm from breaking Breloom's Focus Sash.

  • Ground: Tera Ground-boosted Bulldoze has a 93.8% chance to OHKO 4 HP Gholdengo, making Breloom a situational lure. It also severely punishes Rotom-W that attempt to Volt Switch out, and Hippowdon that don't Terastallize.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Since Breloom's bulk isn't very good, Focus Sash is the most reliable way to fire off Spore.

  • Loaded Dice: Guaranteeing 4 hits from Bullet Seed can be quite useful for bulkier Breloom sets, clinching a OHKO on Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle regardless of them running Substitute or Focus Sash.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: If using Focus Sash, maximizing Speed is important to deal with slower foes that might invest in Speed, such as Corviknight and Skeledirge.

  • 252 HP / 180 Atk / 76 SpD: This bulkier spread makes sense if using Loaded Dice and Swords Dance, letting Breloom survive one hit from Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, or Choice Specs Flutter Mane with the correct Tera type.

sets.name: SubSeed
sets.description:
• With Poison Heal, Breloom can act as a pivot versus defensive Pokemon such as Dondozo and Umbreon as it is unaffected by Yawn.

  • This set can catch opponents expecting the more popular Focus Sash set off guard. However, do note that this set is very susceptible to Taunt and Encore, which can make it difficult to even select Breloom in the team preview phase.

  • Protect: Protect gives Breloom an opportunity to scout out its opponents and further stall them out once Leech Seed has been set up.

  • Timer Stalling: If you obtain a numerical advantage early in the match, you can utilize Breloom to win on timer. This is particularly effective since the Leech Seed damage happens after recovery from Leftovers and Poison Heal.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze allows Breloom to further support its teammates and threaten Gholdengo, which likes to absorb status moves. Do be wary that many Gholdengo are Tera Flying, which can render Breloom ineffective versus it.

Other Options

  • Toxic: Toxic can be difficult to fit into the set, but it allows Breloom to punish Tera Grass foes that attempt to circumvent Breloom's Spore and Leech Seed.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: While Breloom's typing does have some useful resistances, its low bulk means more favorable resistances granted by Terastallization can be key to setting up.

  • Water: This defensive Tera type allows Breloom to resist Baxcalibur's Icicle Spear and Skeledirge's Torch Song, both of which are threats to Substitute. It also helps against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu, though note that Choice Specs Chi-Yu can still OHKO with Tera Fire Overheat.

  • Fire: This Tera type allows Breloom to resist Ice- and Fire-type attacks while also providing Breloom with a Fairy-type resistance. With Toxic, Breloom is able to fight back against common Grass-type switch-ins. However, this type has more weaknesses when compared to Water.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: This spread allows for maximum physical bulk.

  • 156 HP / 100 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread allows for maximum Speed and can survive a Choice Band Extreme Speed from Tera Normal Dragonite after Stealth Rock.

  • 204 HP / 164 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread hits a Speed stat of 108 which ties 4 Spe Adamant Baxcalibur. Furthermore, the defensive investment means that after Terastallization, Breloom's Substitute has a high chance of surviving three hits from Baxcalibur's Icicle Spear.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With threats such as Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Chien-Pao around, Hariyama carves a niche for itself as an Assault Vest user capable of taking them on. Along with its decent bulk, Thick Fat gives it key resistances to Fire- and Ice-type attacks.

  • Bullet Punch: Bullet Punch provides Hariyama with a non-situational priority move that can grab KOs on weakened targets, and, when boosted by Tera Steel, turn the tides against Fairy-type opponents such as Flutter Mane and Mimikyu.

  • Fake Out versus Knock Off: Fake Out gives Hariyama another source of priority, and it can even be used to scout for Covert Cloak users if the opponent doesn't get flinched by it. Knock Off cripples switch-ins by removing their items; however, it can't remove a Booster Energy from an opponent with the Protosynthesis or Quark Drive in Sun or Electric Terrain, respectively, as it's consumed before Hariyama gets to move.

  • Close Combat versus Drain Punch: Close Combat is the stronger move but at the cost of cutting into Hariyama's bulk with each use. Drain Punch can fail to get a 2HKO on specially defensive Ting-Lu more than 90% of the time, but it provides Hariyama with some recovery, bolstering its bulk.

  • Headlong Rush: Headlong Rush drops Hariyama's defenses with each use, but it 2HKOes defensive Toxapex and Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Hariyama a strong option to hit Dragonite with and can catch it by surprise, considering it isn't pressured to Terastallize against Hariyama's other moves.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam, coupled with Tera Steel, provides Hariyama with a strong move against lightweight foes such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Mimikyu, and Terastallized Iron Moth and Volcarona that doesn't drop its defenses.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Hariyama can work without Terastallization, it can provide an extra kick to its coverage or improve its defensive presence against certain threats.

  • Steel: Steel Tera gives Hariyama STAB on Bullet Punch, a resistance to Fairy, Psychic, and Steel, and an immunity to Poison, greatly improving its matchup against Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, Psychic Chi-Yu, Gholdengo, and Tera Fairy Iron Moth and Volcarona. Thanks to Thick Fat, it can take on non-Choice Specs variants of Chi-Yu even after Terastallizing if it's kept healthy.

  • Fire: Besides the burn immunity, Tera Fire capitalizes on Hariyama's Thick Fat, discouraging threats like Tera Fire Chi-Yu and Choice Band Chien-Pao from using their most powerful moves.

  • Fighting: While Tera Fighting doesn't provide anything defensively for Hariyama, it makes Close Combat a force to be reckoned with.

sets.name: Guts Attacker
sets.description:
• Thanks to Guts, Hariyama can work as a status absorber and boost its high Attack at the same time, making it a threat to Toxic Spikes-stacking teams.

  • Bullet Punch: Bullet Punch gives Hariyama a consistent priority move and an option to hit Fairy-type foes.

  • Fake Out versus Knock Off: Fake Out is an option to safely activate Flame Orb and Guts, while Knock Off provides utility in removing items from the opponent.

  • Close Combat versus Drain Punch: Guts-boosted Close Combat is a force to be reckoned with, being one of the few moves capable of OHKOing physically defensive Wo-Chien. Drain Punch is weaker, but the recovery can help offset the burn damage.

  • Earthquake versus Headlong Rush: Earthquake complements Hariyama's coverage nicely, hitting Poison-types that resist Close Combat. Headlong Rush is stronger, but comes with the drawbacks of lowering defenses and being a contact move, triggering Rocky Helmet.

Other Options

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch is Hariyama's best hope of hitting Dragonite, as it doesn't fear much from Hariyama's other moves.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Terastallization gives a much appreciated boost to Bullet Punch, but it isn't necessary on every match.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into the Steel-type turns Hariyama's Fairy and Psychic weaknesses into resistances along with giving STAB to Bullet Punch.

sets.name: Sun Support
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

Salamence.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Specsmence Returns
sets.description:
• Salamence finds a niche for itself among other special attacking Dragon-types due to an incredible ability in Intimidate and a useful typing that provides a handy Fissure immunity.

  • Hurricane versus Air Slash: Hurricane's accuracy may not be very reliable, but the sheer damage output makes it worth it. Air Slash is much weaker than Hurricane, but the more reliable accuracy and flinch chance make it a reasonable alternative. It becomes especially attractive if using Tera Flying.

  • Hydro Pump: If not using Tera Fairy, Hydro Pump is a reasonable choice that deals massive damage to Hippowdon and Fire-types without risking Draco Meteor.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Not only does Tera Fairy give Salamence an edge against many Dragon-types, but it also pairs extremely well with Intimidate, transforming Salamence into an effective hit-and-run threat.

  • Steel: Tera Steel comes in handy against Dragon- and Fairy-types alike, though the added weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make it less effective at taking physical hits with Intimidate.

  • Flying: Air Slash becomes much easier to justify with Tera Flying, and if you're willing to risk it, Hurricane can be used to become almost impossible to wall with Choice Specs.

  • Fire: Tera Fire doesn't offer as much defensive utility, but the powerful STAB attacks come in handy against Steel-types like Corviknight.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon trades defensive advantages for an extremely powerful Draco Meteor that catches defensive foes like Dondozo by surprise.

Items

  • Choice Specs: With Salamence already standing at a decent Speed tier, it can get away with Choice Specs, making it extremely difficult to wall outside of using Blissey.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf trades wallbreaking power for the ability to get the jump on major offensive threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Garchomp.

sets.name: Physically Offensive
sets.description:
• Salamence is somewhat overshadowed by other physical Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragapult, but it has a trick up its claws: Dual Wingbeat, which OHKOes Breloom and Meowscarada through their Focus Sash.

  • Earthquake versus Fire Blast: Earthquake is the best option for hitting Steel-types such as Gholdengo hard, but Fire Blast is Salamence's best shot at 2HKOing Corviknight.

  • Dragon Dance: After a boost, Dual Wingbeat's Focus Sash slaying powers go into overdrive, being able to bust through Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, a boosted Dual Wingbeat has a 75% chance to OHKO offensive Mimikyu through its disguise! It also means Salamence no longer needs a boost to OHKO Great Tusk and Flutter Mane.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Tera Blast Salamence OHKO Azumarill and Iron Bundle, and potentially 2HKO Dondozo after Stealth Rock damage.

Abilities

  • Intimidate: While Salamence isn't particularly bulky, Intimidate makes setting up far easier when paired with a Flying Tera type that removes Salamence's common weaknesses.

  • Moxie: With Moxie, Salamence has the potential to seriously punish Breloom leads or snowball through teams even without Dragon Dance.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
• Salamence's great mixed offenses, Intimidate, and decent Speed give it a niche as a powerful wall breaker.

  • Dual Wingbeat: Dual Wingbeat lets Salamence OHKO Breloom regardless of its Focus Sash, something very few Pokemon can do.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor deals massive damage to Dondozo, usually doing more than 50% to physically defensive ones.

  • Substitute: Substitute makes the Dondozo match-up even better, making Yawn a non-issue. It's also a good way to scout Terastallization against slower threats.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type covers a lot of Salamence's weaknesses and makes dealing with Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane much easier.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Salamence a great match-up against most Dragon-types, and pairs especially well with Intimidate to turn Salamence into a good hit-and-run attacker.

  • Fire: With a Fire Tera type, Salamence gains a resistance to Fairy-type attacks and deals massive damage to Assault Vest Magnezone.

  • Electric: Tera Electric gives Salamence a great tool against Dondozo with Tera Blast.

  • Dragon: While this Tera type fails to help Salamence much defensively, it makes Draco Meteor 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo.

Floatzel.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swift Weasel
sets.description:
• Wave Crash: This is your main offensive option. When further boosted by rain, Tera Water, and Choice Band, it becomes one of the most powerful physical moves in the game, 2HKOing the likes of Bold Amoonguss and OHKOing maximum Defense Corviknight. Mystic Water is an option for flexibility but sacrifices the listed KOs.

  • Liquidation versus Waterfall: Liquidation is a secondary option, and it's preferred when facing frailer offensive teams due to the significant recoil drawback of Wave Crash. However, Waterfall is worth considering for its possible flinch chance.

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet allows Floatzel to maintain offensive presence outside of rain, as well as being a great response to opposing priority moves, such as Kingambit's Sucker Punch.

  • Rain Setter: Pelipper's rain is mandatory for both Swift Swim and maximum damage output.

Tera Types

  • Water: Tera Water massively bolters Floatzel's damage output, and the weasel simply doesn't have the bulk needed for more defensive options.

EV Spreads
