  • Iron Head: If using Tera Steel, this is a reasonable option over Knock Off if Tera Fairy Rotom-W is an issue.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Terastallization can help it clean more easily, it's not an important aspect of this set otherwise.

  • Ground: Tera Ground is the best option for late-game cleaning, dealing significant damage to Dondozo and OHKOing Dragapult with Headlong Rush.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting threatens to 2HKO Corviknight, an otherwise decent check to Great Tusk, and OHKO even the bulkiest Ting-Lu.

  • Steel: While Great Tusk's special bulk is mediocre, Tera Steel can prevent it from being OHKOed by foes such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Since it outspeeds other major Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W, Great Tusk makes for a good revenge killer.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band is a more niche option due to being extremely vulnerable to revenge kills, but does a much better job of wall-breaking, with Tera boosted Great Tusk even being able to 2HKO a maximum Defense Dondozo with Close Combat or Headlong Rush!

Scream Tail.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's incredible support movepool and bulk makes it a fine Stealth Rock supporter.

  • Thunder Wave versus Fling: Thunder Wave is the easiest form of paralysis to fit in, but with Light Ball, Fling can paralyze Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp, and Gholdengo that lack Covert Cloak, at the cost of leaving Scream Tail extremely vulnerable to Encore. Fling can also get rid of devastating Choice items from Trick users such as Rotom-W.

  • Encore: Scream Tail's great Speed tier makes it an especially effective user of Encore, letting it punish foes that attempt to set up, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song is another way for Scream Tail to threaten setup sweepers such as Dragonite, and it can become a win condition late in the game. It's also a fantastic response to Baton Pass foes such as Espathra and opposing Scream Tail.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's additional Speed control is helpful against threats that boost their Speed, such as Dragonite and Baxcalibur.

  • Dazzling Gleam: While a rather weak STAB move, Dazzling Gleam threatening to 2HKO offensive Great Tusk can make it a good way to punish Rapid Spin use.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower 2HKOes Scizor, though it does not 2HKO Gholdengo, making Recover sets still problematic.

  • Disable: Disable is particularly apt at ruining Choice item foes that need a specific move to 2HKO Scream Tail, such as Scizor, though compared to Encore, it's less useful against support moves.

  • Psychic Fangs: In addition to 2HKOing Iron Moth, Psychic Fangs breaking dual screens can be extremely useful, though this doesn't work against Grimmsnarl.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal might seem like an underwhelming defensive option, but taking on Ghost-type attacks while avoiding a 2HKO from Gholdengo can be valuable.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives a vital Steel resistance and is a great defensive typing in general.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Scream Tail's matchup against Dark-types such as Hydreigon.

  • Fire: If using Flamethrower, Tera Fire Scream Taill will have a 97.3% chance to 2HKO Tera Steel Scizor, making it an effective lure.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Blocking the first use of Taunt makes Scream Tail an extremely reliable setter of Stealth Rock.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is the safest way to increase Scream Tail's longetivity, and it can avoid certain 2HKOs depending on the EV spread, such as that from Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump with specially defensive spreads.

  • Light Ball: Light Ball is a requirement when using Fling, ensuring Scream Tail can inflict paralysis once and get rid of Choice items with one move.

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy being instantly consumed makes Scream Tail less flexible, but boosting Speed lets it outspeed key threats such as Dragapult. This item can also be used with bulkier EV spreads to make Scream Tail even bulkier, pulling off incredible stunts such as surviving Timid Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

EV Spreads

  • Scream Tail has an incredible number of viable EV spreads at its disposal: consider these as mere examples rather than all of its viable EV spreads!

  • 180 HP / 156 SpD / 172 Spe with Calm or Careful: This EV spread outspeeds Baxcalibur and Great Tusk and survives Timid Choice Specs Iron Moth's Sludge Wave 93.7% of the time.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: The Speed investment outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and Scream Tail avoids OHKOs from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane.

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Calm or Careful: This EV spread avoids an OHKO from Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and Scream Tail has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Scizor's Choice Band Bullet Punch. If outspeeding Baxcalibur and Great Tusk is a must, a Speed-boosting nature and 68 Speed EVs can be used instead.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid or Jolly: With maximum Speed investment, Scream Tail outspeeds not only Iron Moth, but also major Encore targets such as Garchomp and Annihilape.

sets.name: Baton Pass
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's diverse setup options and bulk make it one of the most unpredictable Baton Pass Pokemon in the metagame.

  • Encore: Encore is perfect for punishing passive play, giving Scream Tail many new setup opportunities.

  • Sing: Sing is a high-risk, high-reward option to set up in otherwise impossible situations, and it is especially effective with Blunder Policy.

  • Substitute: Not only is Substitute useful to pass with Baton Pass, but it makes weak Pokemon such as Garganacl into easy setup bait.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: When using Calm Mind, Flamethrower can threaten Gholdengo and Scizor.

  • Psychic Fangs: Psychic Fangs 2HKOes Clodsire and, after a Bulk Up boost, can OHKO Iron Moth that don't invest in Defense. However, Grimmsnarl holds back its dual screens-breaking potential.

  • Drain Punch: Drain Punch gives Scream Tail some offensive presence against Kingambit.

  • Stored Power: When combined with Calm Mind and Blunder Policy, Stored Power can threaten Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal gets rid of Scream Tail's key weakness to Steel, and it performs well against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo in particular.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Scream Tail a fantastic defensive typing, resisting Scizor's Bullet Punch in particular.

  • Dark: If Grimmsnarl is particularly problematic for your team, Tera Dark will block its Prankster Taunt from stopping Scream Tail.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Mental Herb is the most reliable option for getting Baton Pass off against faster Taunt users.

  • Blunder Policy: When paired with Sing, Scream Tail can pass Speed when Sing misses.

  • Sitrus Berry: A burst of recovery from Sitrus Berry eases setup in general.

  • Booster Energy: While it's impossible to pass Protosynthesis boosts via Baton Pass, either outspeeding disruptive foes such as Iron Bundle, or surviving Choice Specs holders like Iron Moth and Gholdengo, can be a deadly surprise.

General EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Careful or Calm: This EV spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to survive Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and it has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: This spread outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and with Blunder Policy, it can even outspeed Booster Energy Iron Bundle after missing Sing. The bulk lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly or Timid: Maximizing Speed lets Scream Tail outspeed high-profile targets such as Iron Moth and Garchomp.

Blunder Policy-Specific EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Careful or Calm: This spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to usually survive Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also outspeeds Booster Energy Iron Valiant after missing Sing. The remaining 8 EVs can only boost Special Defense and an offensive stat of your choice.

  • 180 HP / 212 SpD / 116 Spe with Jolly or Timid and 180 HP / 100 SpD / 228 Spe with Careful or Calm: These functionally identical stat spreads let Scream Tail outspeed even Choice Scarf Dragapult after missing Sing! The Special Defense investment lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's bulk and impressive Speed make it a great dual screens setter.

  • Encore: Encore punishing setup is extremely valuable considering Scream Tail's passive nature compared to other dual screens setters.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song can ruin Baton Pass attempts from the likes of Espathra or opposing Scream Tail, and it does well against most setup sweepers, except Gholdengo.

  • Light Clay versus Mental Herb: Light Clay is the preferred choice, but Mental Herb can save Scream Tail from some particularly difficult users of Taunt such as Corviknight and Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • The extreme support focus of this set means that Terastallization should only be used as a last resort, or when it can clearly lead to a win.

  • Normal: In emergencies, Tera Normal can let Scream Tail set up dual screens against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. Note that Scream Tail is completely passive against Gholdengo, though.

  • Dark: Tera Dark is a niche answer to Prankster Taunt users such as Grimmsnarl.

Brute Bonnet.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Speedy Spore
sets.description:
• Don't be fooled by Brute Bonnet's low Speed stat; after two uses of Trailblaze, it even outspeeds Dragapult, which is a very feasible feat thanks to Spore. With the lack of Sleep Clause, this Speed turns Brute Bonnet into a terrifying sleep inducer!

  • Crunch versus Sucker Punch: Crunch is the preferred STAB move, reliably hitting the most common Spore check, Gholdengo, which makes it the ideal STAB attack to use with Substitute. However, Sucker Punch lets Brute Bonnet pick off threats when it doesn't have the chance to Spore and set up Trailblaze.

  • Close Combat versus Substitute: On one hand, Close Combat deals massive damage to Dark-type resistances, such as Roaring Moon, but it leaves Brute Bonnet fairly vulnerable to priority attacks. On the other hand, Spore gives Brute Bonnet ample opportunity to set up Substitute, easing the cost of early wake ups.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Powering up Crunch makes it easier to sweep with Crunch or Sucker Punch while still leaving it immune to Grimmsnarl's Prankster Taunt.

  • Fire: Tera Fire turns Brute Bonnet's devastating U-turn and Fairy-type weaknesses into resistances, giving it the edge against Flutter Mane and letting it fry Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Poison: Tera Poison grants Brute Bonnet important resistances to U-turn, Fighting, and Fairy without compromising itself against Water-types.

  • Fairy: With Tera Fairy, Brute Bonnet deals with Dragon-types far more reliably, and gains a valuable tool against opposing Dark- and Dragon-types with Tera Blast.

EV Spreads

  • 148 HP / 100 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Adamant: With Adamant, Brute Bonnet will still outspeed Great Tusk and Annihilape after Trailblaze and Dragapult after two uses of Trailblaze. Brute Bonnet's bulk lets it survive some powerful attacks, such as Iron Moth's Sludge Wave, Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain, and almost always surviving Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: At the cost of bulk, maximizing Speed lets Brute Bonnet outspeed threats such as Garchomp and Iron Treads after just one use of Trailblaze

Items

  • Booster Energy: Activating Protosynthesis takes dvantage of Brute Bonnet's power, though it means switching out will weaken Brute Bonnet.

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers is by far the preferred item, as Brute Bonnet has plenty of turns to recover its health against sleeping foes.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb is the most consistent way to boost Brute Bonnet's power, letting it switch out after using Spore when needed.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Brute Bonnet's good bulk, Focus Sash is a great option to stop potential sweeps, assuming entry hazards aren't set up.

sets.name: Bulky Spore
sets.description:
• With good bulk and access to strong priority, Brute Bonnet is a great offensive user of Spore.

  • Bullet Seed versus Seed Bomb: Even when not using Loaded Dice, Bullet Seed is useful for potentially KOing foes like Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane through Focus Sash and punishing Mimikyu switch ins. Nontheless, Seed Bomb is the more reliable option when not using Loaded Dice.

  • Substitute: Substitute is easy to set up thanks to Spore and eases the risk early wake-ups can pose. If using Substitute, using Crunch or Payback over Sucker Punch is preferred due to the issues Substitute Gholdengo can cause.

  • Crunch versus Payback: Having a reliable Dark-type STAB move is helpful when facing foes like Substitute Gholdengo. Payback has higher damage potential, but Crunch won't have its power dropped by foes switching in.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat crushes Roaring Moon and opposing Brute Bonnet, though the drop in bulk can be troublesome for this set.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Tera Dark works fantastically with Sucker Punch, giving Brute Bonnet good revenge killing capability.

  • Poison: Tera Poison covers Brute Bonnet's major weaknesses to U-turn, Fairy, and Fighting, giving it an easy chance to use Spore.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness can be troublesome, Tera Fire still does well against Flutter Mane and lets Brute Bonnet melt Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Outrage and Draco Meteor can be turned into Spore bait with Tera Fairy, in addition to arming Brute Bonnet with a powerful Tera Blast against them.

  • Grass: If using Bullet Seed, Tera Grass can make sense for increasing the chance of shooting down Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane and still keeping the Spore immunity against Breloom and opposing Brute Bonnet.

Items

  • Leftovers: The extra recovery pairs very well with Spore and Substitute.

  • Sitrus Berry: If not using Substitute, the quick burst of recovery with Sitrus Berry is preferred.

  • Loaded Dice: Guaranteeing 4 hits with Bullet Seed means Brute Bonnet will always OHKO Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle through their Focus Sash, and the higher chance for 5 hits can even shoot down Mimikyu and offensive Great Tusk.

Flutter Mane.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane's blistering Speed and Special Attack along with its powerful unresisted STAB combination exerts an oppressive amount of pressure on most teams, making it one of the premier offensive Pokemon in the format.

  • Mystical Fire: Mystical Fire heavily disrupts enemy special attackers, especially in tandem with its already impressive base 135 Special Defense.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock significantly dents defensive checks like Clodsire and Toxapex, deals massive damage to Iron Moth, and gets arounds Special Defense boosting from the likes of Quiver Dance Volcarona.

  • Substitute: Calm Mind + Substitute is a classic duo that grealty assists Flutter Mane's setup attempts, allowing it to set up infront of Toxapex.

  • Calm Mind: A fast Calm Mind utilizes Flutter Mane's naturally strong Special Defense to set up against other special attackers. This is especially strong for winning Flutter Mane mirrors: if your Flutter Mane goes first, it can cushion even an opposing Choice Specs Shadow Ball with the Special Defense boost, then fire back next turn with a +1 Shadow Ball of its own.

  • Perish Song: This is an effective late-game win condition against a wide variety of Pokemon, and is one of the best ways to shut down Baton Pass foes like Espathra in the game.

Other Options

  • Taunt and Thunder Wave: Taunt and Thunder Wave take advantage of Flutter Mane's incredible Speed to disrupt opposing setup strategies, though these options tend to be less reliable than Charm sets.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Flutter Mane's incredible Speed is put to good use, outspeeding almost everything in the metagame with the major exceptions being Booster Energy Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Dragapult.

  • Choice Specs: With Choice Specs, Flutter Mane becomes a potent wall breaker, 2HKOing almost anything that doesn't resist it.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash patches up Flutter Mane's poor physical bulk, giving it new revenge kill chances.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf's consistent Speed boost allows Flutter Mane to run EV spreads that give a better balance of bulk and power, since Speed no longer has to be the highest stat for Booster Energy boosts.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: While Flutter Mane benefits from Terastallization, it's generally flexible enough to go without it.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy makes Moonblast a potent sweeping move, while reducing damage against Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch and Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

  • Water: Tera Water has a niche for giving a resistance to Steel, Ice, and Fire, giving improved matchups against Scizor, Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is a purely defensive option, ridding Flutter Mane of its troublesome Ghost-type weakness.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Flutter Mane a resistance to Steel, most notably living Scizor's Bullet Punch. It also boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost powering up Shadow Ball can be a devastating surprise against bulky Fairy resistances such as Iron Moth.

EV Spreads

  • Flutter Mane's lack of physical bulk makes it extremely vulnerable to getting revenge killed, so consider these alternative EV spreads if a simple offensive spread is not working well. Note that Flutter Mane has many more viable EV spreads, these are just examples!

EV Spreads That Boost Speed With Protosynthesis

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 148 SpA / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Timid: This EV spread outspeeds up to Iron Moth, survives Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash, and almost always avoids a 2HKO from Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump when it lacks Choice Specs.

  • 188 HP / 228 Def / 20 SpA / 4 SpD / 68 Spe with Timid: This spread survives Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock damage and outspeeds Iron Moth and the rare Scream Tail.

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Bold or Timid: This extremely defensive spread allows Flutter Mane to survive Tera Dark Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch without needing to Terastallize itself, while still outspeeding Jolly Annihilape. If outspeeding Timid Chi-Yu and Jolly Garchomp is more important, Flutter Mane can use Timid instead of Bold at the cost of some bulk against priority.

  • 116 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 132 Spe with Timid: This EV spread outspeeds Jolly Roaring Moon and survives an opposing Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball without Terastallization. In addition, Life Orb Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak has a fairly low chance of OHKOing, and Iron Bundle fails to KO with the combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze Dry.

EV Spreads That Don't Boost Speed With Protosynthesis

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 92 SpA / 4 SpD / 116 Spe with Modest: This spread outspeeds Jolly Garchomp and Timid Chi-Yu, survives Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash. and has a very likely chance of surviving two Hydro Pumps from Iron Bundle when it's not using Choice Specs.

  • 188 HP / 228 Def / 76 SpA / 4 SpD / 12 Spe with Modest: This EV spread only outspeeds up to Jolly Annihilape, but in exchange, has more power than most Flutter Mane and survives Life Orb Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Charm
sets.description:
• The combination of Charm and Pain Split turns Flutter Mane into a devastating control option, massively crippling opposing offensive threats and healing itself with the combination of Pain Split and Draining Kiss.

  • Calm Mind versus coverage: Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to maintain its role as a sweeper by increasing its damage output while simultaneously reinforcing its longevity. However, this leaves Flutter Mane quite vulnerable to Steel-types, so Shadow Ball and Mystical Fire are reasonable alternatives.

  • Draining Kiss versus Moonblast: Moonblast's far superior damage output is a great option versus more defensive teams, while Draining Kiss supplies superior lasting power against more offensive teams.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Since this Flutter Mane is trying to defeat unexpected physical threats one-on-one, Terastallization is great at patching up some matchups that Charm can't on its own, even if it's not required for this set to work.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy Further boosts Moonblast's impressive damage output while removing Flutter Mane's Ghost weakness.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Flutter Mane a very useful resistance to Steel, Ice, and Fire, giving it improved matchups against Scizor, Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Fire: Tera Fire helps Flutter Mane deal with Scizor and boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

EV Spreads

  • 124 HP / 252 Def / 132 Spe with Timid: The chosen EVs ensure that Flutter Mane will always outspeed Jolly Booster Energy Roaring Moon. Maximum Defense investment gets the most out of Charm with the rest placed into HP.

Slither Wing.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Sandy Shocks.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Iron Treads.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon has a few niches in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With a decent defensive typing in Ground / Steel and good bulk, Iron Treads can run an effective Assault Vest set.

  • Iron Head versus Heavy Slam: While Heavy Slam is not as consistent as Iron Head due to Iron Treads's middling weight, it reaches maximum power against targets such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant. Heavy Slam gets a OHKO on Iron Valiant and 2HKOes Iron Bundle, which is something that's not achievable with Iron Head, however, Iron Head 2HKOes Baxcalibur, and does non-negligible damage to Dragonite, which isn't possible with Heavy Slam.

  • Rapid Spin: It may seem weird to run Rapid Spin on such a fast-paced-format, but with it, Iron Treads can support teammates like Dragonite and Focus Sash Flutter Mane. Additionally, with a Jolly nature and minimal Speed investment Iron Treads can outrun Timid Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner gives Iron Treads a move to hit Dragonite, Hydreigon, Garchomp, and Great Tusk hard.

  • Knock Off: Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move against Rotom-W and Rotom-H, and its item removal is valuable all around, crippling both the Pokemon it's supposed to check as well as common switch-ins.

  • Volt Switch: Pivoting can help Iron Treads against physically bulky Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Terastallized Garganacl.

  • EV Spread: The EV Spread aims to maximize Iron Treads's ability to take special attacks, especially when coupled with an Assault Vest; the Speed allows it to outspeed Jolly Breloom before a Rapid Spin and Timid Iron Bundle.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying provides Iron Treads with a Ground immunity and a Fighting resistance, along with neutralizing its Fire weakness, which can be useful against Tera Fire Flutter Mane and Sylveon, Skeledirge, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description:
• Iron Treads possesses an incredible support movepool along with a great base 106 Speed stat, making it a great support option.

  • Electric Terrain: A manual Electric Terrain may seem odd, but Iron Treads has the bulk to run it and use it to activate its own Quark Drive along with its teammates' if applicable, and the lack of other Terrains in the current series means Electric Terrain can run for its full duration a lot of times. Electric Terrain also blocks sleep moves from foes such as Skeledirge, Espathra, Iron Valiant, Gengar, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Rapid Spin: Despite the fast-paced-nature of BSS, Rapid Spin allows Iron Treads to both boost its speed and clear entry hazards from its side of the field, supporting teammates such as Focus Sash Iron Bundle and Dragonite.

  • Knock Off: Along with its item removal ability, Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move to hit Rotom-W and Rotom-H.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner allows Iron Treads to hit foes such as Dragonite and Great Tusk hard, but it should be used carefully if it's run alongside Electric Terrain, as it ends the current active Terrain.

Other Options

  • Heavy Slam: With Heavy Slam, Iron Treads can OHKO Iron Valiant, as well as 2HKO Iron Bundle without Tera Steel. After Terastallizing into Steel, Heavy Slam can OHKO Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Wild Charge: If Iron Treads is holding a Life Orb, Wild Charge is capable of 2HKOing Corviknight in Electric Terrain.

  • Bulldoze: While weaker than Earthquake, Bulldoze is a speed control option for Iron Treads that affects Ghost-types, unlike Rapid Spin.

Tera Types

  • Ground: Tera Ground neutralizes Iron Treads's Fire, Ground, and Fighting weaknesses and ramps up the power of its Earthquake.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gets rid of Iron Treads's Water weakness and gives it resistances to Ice and Grass.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy increases Iron Treads's speed even further, allowing it to outspeed Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Dragapult and slower Choice Scarf foes, making it very likely to get a move off first.

  • Terrain Extender: Terrain Extender increases the duration of Terrains to eight turns, giving Iron Treads or one of its Quark Drive teammates more turns to make use of their ability.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is an option for ensuring Iron Treads can get at least one move off against faster foes that can KO it.

  • Air Balloon: An Air Balloon allows Iron Treads to have an edge against other Ground-type leads such as Garchomp.

  • Life Orb: When used alongside Electric Terrain, Life Orb boosts Iron Treads's offensive pressure, and a Terrain-boosted Wild Charge can 2HKO Corviknight.

Iron Bundle.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Santa's Slay
sets.description:
• With nearly perfect coverage and an incredible Speed stat, Iron Bundle's ferocious brand of holiday spirit is a metagame-defining force!

  • Encore: Giving the gift of an encore lets Iron Bundle punish passive Pokemon and naughty sweepers alike.

  • Ice Beam: With a power-boosting item, Ice Beam OHKOes Dragonite through Multiscale, and Ursaluna after one turn of burn damage.

  • Flip Turn: Pivoting is a big help when Iron Bundle is facing Pokemon likely to Terastallize such as Heatran and Ursaluna, or against bulky Assault Vest foes such as Hisuian Goodra and Baxcalibur.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Iron Bundle take further advantage of encored Pokemon and is a decent way to scout for Tera types when using Booster Energy or Life Orb. It's especially effective at punishing Sucker Punch revenge killers such as Chien-Pao.

Other Options

  • Taunt: Taunt will make support Pokemon such as Clodsire and Tinkaton want to take a holiday, though watch out for common users of Mental Herb such as Toxapex.

  • Whirlpool: Although difficult to pull off with Iron Bundle's mediocre bulk, trapping foes with Whirlpool can make Encore especially deadly.

  • Electric Terrain: Giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost via Electric Terrain isn't nearly as flexible as Booster Energy, but it does let Iron Bundle support potentially deadly Quark Drive teammates such as Iron Valiant and Iron Hands.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Iron Bundle's perfect coverage and high Speed means its fairly flexible with a team's Terastallization needs.

  • Water: Besides the power boost for Hydro Pump, Tera Water enables a reliable Water-type STAB move in Tera Blast and avoids a OHKO from Choice Scarf Urshifu-R's Close Combat.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Iron Bundle an important immunity to Extreme Speed, which can especially ruin Dragonite's holiday with Encore.

  • Ice: With Tera Ice, Freeze-Dry will OHKO offensive Dragonite through Multiscale and Ice Beam will OHKO even bulky Dragonite and most Assault Vest Thundurus-T.

  • Ground: An immunity to Electric-type attacks lets Iron Bundle potentially give Zapdos, Thundurus-T, and Rotom-W's momentum a snow day and deal more damage to Gholdengo via Tera Blast.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Quark Drive's Speed boost lets Iron Bundle outpace key Choice Scarf and Booster threats such as Flutter Mane, Urshifu-R, Thundurus-T, Greninja, and Dragonite.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs Iron Bundle regifts support moves so it can wallbreak, with moves such as Tera Water Hydro Pump now OHKOing physically defensive Ting-Lu.

  • Focus Sash: Getting around Iron Bundle's iffy bulk makes it a fantastic lead and revenge killer.

  • Life Orb: While Life Orb compromises Iron Bundle's ability to take priority attacks, it boosts damage without passing on powerful support moves.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 44 HP / 12 Def / 148 SpA / 52 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid: This bulkier spread survives Jolly Chien-Pao's Sacred Sword and Timid Flutter Mane's Moonblast.

Iron Hands.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: CATCH THESE HANDS (Assault Vest)
sets.description:
• With its great Attack, its good natural bulk, and a healing move in Drain Punch, Iron Hands stands out as a premier Assault Vest attacker.

  • Thunder Punch versus Wild Charge: Wild Charge lets Iron Hands muscle through bulky foes like physically defensive Dondozo at the cost of longevity.

  • Fake Out: Fake Out picks off weakened, normally faster threats, such as Dragonite and Volcarona. It can also beat Focus Sash leads, such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Iron Hands a good option to hit Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam is Iron Hands's best option to hit Fairy-types, notably OHKOing Flutter Mane.

  • Volt Switch: Volt Switch, though incredibly weak, can scout switches and maintain offensive momentum.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: While Iron Hands will function without Terastallizing, it'll be needed to handle Choice Specs Flutter Mane, argubly the most dangerous special attacker in the metagame, as well as handle Ground coverage more reasonably.

  • Ground: Tera Ground gives Iron Hands a strong Earthquake and removes most of its common weaknesses.

  • Grass: Tera Grass giving Spore immunity can stop Breloom cold if it doesn't Terastallize. The Ground-type resistance also lets Iron Hands square up with Ting-Lu much more effectively.

  • Water: Tera Water's Ice and Fire resistances help a lot against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu.

  • Fairy: A Fairy-type Tera allows Iron Hands to take advantage of its great bulk by giving it a better defensive typing, though previously walled Steel-types like Gholdengo and Magnezone become a lot more threatening.

  • Flying: Tera Flying lets Iron Hands completely flip its matchup against Ground-types like Garchomp and Great Tusk and dodge Fissure attempts from the likes of Dondozo and Ting-Lu.

  • Electric:Tera Electric elevates Thunder Punch's power to more acceptable levels, makes Wild Charge very difficult to switch into, and removes Iron Hands's weakness to Fairy.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting allows Iron Hands to deal more damage with Drain Punch while also removing its weakness to Ground-type attacks.

  • Steel: Tera Steel grants a resistance to Fairy and boosts Heavy Slam's power, drastically improving Iron Hands's matchup against Flutter Mane.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 204 SpD / 52 Spe with Adamant: Because Iron Hands is in a highly contested Speed tier with Azumarill and Kingambit, some Speed investment is very helpful. 52 Speed EVs is a substantial boost to help with this while also jumping above the next Speed tier, outrunning targets like 4 Speed Blissey and Brute Bonnet.

  • 252 Atk / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Adamant: Going with a simple spread that maximizes power and special bulk is still a very effective option for Iron Hands.

sets.name: Bulky Substitute
sets.description:
• Iron Hands's incredible bulk gives it one of the game's strongest Substitutes, letting it set up on a unique list of threats.

  • Swords Dance: Swords Dance lets Iron Hands set up on the passive foes it blocks with Substitute. The Attack boost also pairs very well with Drain Punch, keeping Iron Hands healthy and making it much harder to break.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch provides more immediate damage against pure Ground-types and the ever-present Dragonite.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake hits Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Tera Fire Chi-Yu hard. It also does well against foes that try to block Drain Punch with Tera Poison.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Despite having a strong bulk profile, Iron Hands frequently needs to remove its common Ground- and Fairy-type weaknesses to be effective.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy removes all of Iron Hands's most troublesome weaknesses while also granting a powerful Dragon-type immunity. This does, however, make Iron Hands much easier to revenge kill with Gholdengo and Iron Moth.

  • Water: Tera Water is another solid defensive option that drastically improves the Chi-Yu matchup. Likewise, the resistance to Ice is fantastic against Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur, with the latter no longer being able to rely on Icicle Spear to effectively break through Substitute.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting boosts Drain Punch's output while removing Iron Hands's Ground weakness.

  • Fire: Tera Fire can block Will-O-Wisp from support Dragapult and Rotom formes, which otherwise outspeed and burn Iron Hands if it doesn't already have Substitute up.

  • Grass: Tera Grass can turn the tide against faster Grass-types like Breloom and Wo-Chien, blocking their status moves and buying a free turn to start setting up.

EV Spreads

  • 92 HP / 4 Atk / 172 Def / 212 SpD / 28 Spe with Impish: The defensive investment keeps uninvested Dondozo's Wave Crash from breaking Iron Hands's Substitute, providing superior protection from Fissure spam. After Terastallizing, non-STAB Earthquake from the likes of Dragonite and Baxcalibur often fails to break Substitute as well. On the specially defensive side, a full health Iron Hands can survive a Fire Blast from Modest Tera Fire Chi-Yu.

teams.name: Substitute + Swords Dance Set added by

Iron Jugulis.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have some niches in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
• While not quite as powerful or versatile as its counterpart Hydreigon, Iron Jugulis fills a unique role due to its higher Speed and Flying-type STAB.

  • Hurricane vs Air Slash: Hurricane secures KOs on Pokemon like Iron Bundle that Air Slash cannot, however, Air Slash is much less likely to miss, and the flinch chance can come in handy occasionally.

  • Taunt: With Taunt, Iron Jugulis stops walls such as Clodsire from healing off its attacks, and prevents debilitating status that would otherwise cut its sweep short.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power grants Iron Jugulis valuable coverage on most Pokémon that would not mind its main attacks, like Tinkaton.

  • Flash Cannon: Flash Cannon is useful for hitting Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane for big damage.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower provides super effective coverage on Steel-types that might otherwise cause issues for Iron Jugulis.

Other Options

  • Knock Off: While not doing much damage to many does due to Iron Jugulis's thoroughly average Attack stat, Knock Off can still help Iron Jugulis and its teammates by softening up defensive cores via item removal.

  • Substitute: Substitute can be used to punish Spore attempts from the likes of Breloom and Brute Bonnet, as well as easing prediction by scouting switches.

  • Focus Blast: Though unreliable due to its accuracy, Focus Blast is Iron Jugulis's best option to hit Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Terastallizing into a Flying-type boosts Iron Jugulis's damage output with Air Slash and Hurricane, making it even more difficult to switch into while removing the weaknesses that come from its secondary Dark typing.

  • Dark: A Dark-type Tera boosts Dark Pulse's damage considerably, and when coupled with its rather high flinch rate, a Tera Dark Iron Jugulis can prove quite difficult to handle for some teams.

  • Steel: A Steel-type Tera grants Iron Jugulis a resistance to Fairy and Ice, improving its matchup with Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle and giving it STAB on Flash Cannon.

  • Ground: Tera Ground gives Iron Jugulis an Electric-type immunity, allowing it to block Volt Switch from the likes of Rotom-W and Iron Hands while also giving it STAB on Earth Power.

sets.name: NANO LOVE (Choice Item)
sets.description:
• With its good Speed and powerful STABs, Iron Jugulis lends itself nicely to use a Choice item set, setting itself apart from Hydreigon by virtue of its higher Speed at the cost of some power.

  • Hurricane vs Air Slash: Hurricane offers Iron Jugulis an extremely powerful Flying-type STAB attack, though Air Slash is far more consistent due to its higher accuracy.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power allows Iron Jugulis to hit otherwise irritating switch-ins like Magnezone and Tinkaton.

  • Flash Cannon: Flash Cannon allows Iron Jugulis to punish Fairy-type switch-ins such as Flutter Mane, as well as the numerous Tera Fairy users in the BSS metagame.

  • U-turn: U-turn allows Iron Jugulis to keep momentum for its team by scouting switches and pivoting out of disadvantageous matchups.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs elevates Iron Jugulis's power, allowing it to wallbreak much more consistently.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf's Speed boost allows Iron Jugulis to outspeed otherwise faster foes like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, potentially surprising them with early KOs.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying boosts Air Slash to more respectable power levels, and also makes Hurricane incredibly hard to switch into safely.

  • Dark: Tera Dark pushes Dark Pulse's damage output even further, making Iron Jugulis very hard to deal with in conjunction with the move’s ever-irritating flinch rate.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Iron Jugulis resistances to Fairy and Ice, improving its matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

Iron Moth.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Excellent offensive stats, the useful ability to absorb Toxic Spikes, and good coverage make Iron Moth one of the best choices for an offensive Fire-type, even with Chi-Yu being a major competitor for it.

  • Energy Ball: Energy Ball is highly recommended to hit Dondozo hard and OHKO Iron Bundle if not using Choice Specs. It also deals massive damage to Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Hippowdon.

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam is the best option against Dragon-types such as Garchomp and Roaring Moon.

  • Overheat: Even with the lack of extra coverage, Overheat is so strong that very few Pokemon can safely switch into it.

  • Psychic: Psychic is Iron Moth's best shot of winning the mirror match and doing big damage to Toxapex. It's also an option to do good damage against common bulky Tera Poison Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Annihilape, and Wo-Chien.

Other Options

  • Acid Spray: Acid Spray can be a way to get past Skeledirge that lack Earth Power, and a good way to break down Ting-Lu's tanking capabilities. If using Choice Specs and Tera Poison, it becomes extremely difficult to check defensively without Ting-Lu.

  • Discharge: Discharge trades hitting Rotom-W hard for Toxapex, at the cost of being far more vulnerable against Ground-types.

  • Flame Charge: If not using a Choice Item, coverage can be sacrificed in exchange for giving Iron Moth the ability to outspeed major threats such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult.

  • U-turn: Iron Moth is fully capable of being a reasonable pivot, though U-turn is rather weak.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Iron Moth's sheer offensive power and good Speed tier means Terastallization isn't integral to it, but it can be a good tool to stop revenge kills.

  • Grass: Tera Grass massively improves Iron Moth's matchup against common Ground-types like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Garchomp, and the high powered Energy Ball helps against Palafin-H and Assault Vest Azumarill. The immunity to Spore can help in a pinch against Brute Bonnet and Breloom too.

  • Water: With Tera Blast, Tera Water improves the Chi-Yu and Iron Moth matchup.

  • Fire: When paired with Overheat and Choice Specs, Tera Fire means Fire-resistant foes aren't safe; even physically defensive Skeledirge is 2HKOed!

  • Fairy: The Dark-type resistance Tera Fairy provides can be a good way to catch Chien-Pao off guard after its Focus Sash has been broken. The boost given to Dazzling Gleam also makes Tera Fairy far more effective against Dragon-types, now being able to OHKO Dragapult and even OHKO Garchomp if using Choice Specs.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Sludge Wave good damage potential and removes Iron Moth's annoying Stealth Rock weakness. It also turns Acid Spray into a deadly wall-breaking move.

Items

  • Booster Energy: While Booster Energy does make this Iron Moth less flexible in terms of switching out, the extra power can allow Iron Moth to run bulkier EV spreads, and the lack of recoil like Life Orb can make it a good late-game cleaner too.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs turns Iron Moth into a full blown wallbreaker.

  • Assault Vest: Iron Moth's good special bulk makes Assault Vest a fine choice, letting it survive new attacks such as an unboosted Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle and Rotom-W. It can be paired with bulkier EV spreads for even more impressive feats!

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf outspeeds important threats such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, who could otherwise outpseed and KO Iron Moth. Note that this item does compete heavily with the more powerful Chi-Yu, so make sure aspects of Iron Moth like Toxic Spikes absorption are important to the team.

Bulkier EV Spreads

  • 164 HP / 100 Def / 60 SpA / 4 SpD / 180 Spe with Modest: This EV spread survives Tera Normal Choice Band Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Life Orb Chien-Pao's Throat Chop from full health, survives two Shadow Balls from Modest Flutter Mane that lack an offensive boost, and outspeeds Modest Chi-Yu, Jolly Baxcalibur, and Jolly Great Tusk. If using Assualt Vest, even Choice Specs Flutter Mane fails to 2HKO with Shadow Ball!

  • 140 HP / 28 Def / 160 SpA / 180 Spe with Modest: This Assault Vest based spread avoids a 2HKO from Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball, and OHKOes Iron Bundle with Fiery Dance.

sets.name: Speedy Booster Energy
sets.description:
• With Booster Energy in its circuits, Iron Moth can sacrifice some of its power to become a surprisingly effective late-game sweeper and emergency revenge killer.

  • Energy Ball: Energy Ball is the best option for dealing damage to bulky Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk, and it also OHKOes Iron Bundle.

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam is Iron Moth's ticket to overloading Dragon-types like Garchomp and Roaring Moon, who can otherwise stop a sweep.

  • Psychic: While not providing great coverage overall, Psychic is Iron Moth's best move against Toxapex and opposing Iron Moth, and is still a reasonable option against Great Tusk.

  • Sludge Wave versus Acid Spray: Sludge Wave is the more reliable STAB move for dealing big damage to Azumarill and common Tera Fairy foes such as Garchomp and Rotom-W. Acid Spray on its own is weak without Tera Poison, but it presents Iron Moth a chance to soften up bulky switch-ins such as Ting-Lu and Assault Vest Baxcalibur.

  • EV Spread: The given EV Spread ensures Iron Moth gets a Speed boost upon consuming Booster Energy while also surviving a neutral 120 BP attack from Great Tusk without an offensive item thanks to Terastallization.

Other Options

  • Discharge: Discharge is an alternative over Energy Ball, being a move that hits Water-types hard without leaving Iron Moth walled in mirror matches.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium If saved for late game, Iron Moth can often get itself in a position to sweep without worrying about revenge kills. Terastallization however, can reduce its vulnerability to certain priority attacks and allow it to be used earlier.

  • Grass: Tera Grass is among the best options, preventing foes like Azumarill and Garchomp from easily stopping a late-game sweep, plus dealing big damage to physically defensive Ting-Lu with Energy Ball.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Fiery Dance's somewhat underwhelming damage output can be overcome, now letting Iron Moth OHKO Iron Bundle.

  • Water: If paired with Tera Blast, Tera Water is usually the best option against Chi-Yu, Skeledirge, and opposing Iron Moth.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy punishes Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu that attempt to revenge kill with their Dark-type STABs, in addition to dealing far more damage to Dragon-types with Dazzling Gleam.

  • Poison: Tera Poison makes Acid Spray a powerful wallbreaking tool, in addition to letting Sludge Wave OHKO defensive Tera Fairy Garchomp.

sets.name: Bulky Toxic Spikes Setter
sets.description:
• Iron Moth may seem like a strange Pokemon to use as a bulky Toxic Spikes setter, but it sets itself apart from other Pokemon like Toxapex thanks to being far less passive.

  • Fiery Dance: While Fiery Dance is not a particularly reliable away to sweep, taking the chance is worth it considering Iron Moth's Speed.

  • Whirlwind: A phazing move may not seemingly gel well with Speed investment, but it has incredible utility when Toxic Spikes are set up, punishing teams that leave their Toxic Spikes absorber in on Iron Moth.

  • Sludge Wave versus Tera Blast: Giving up on Whirlwind does lose a unique selling point as a Toxic Spikes setter, but in exchange makes Iron Moth much harder to check with Fire-type checks like Azumarill and Chi-Yu. Sludge Wave is preferred for its reliability, but Tera Blast makes sense with certain Tera Types like Water.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: When the aim is to simply set up Toxic Spikes, Terastallization is not that important. However, Iron Moth's typing gives it enough weaknesses that Terastallization can give it a far longer life span.

  • Water: Tera Water gives Iron Moth a resistance to Water moves without losing its resistance to Ice and Fire, which is helpful against Chien-Pao and Chi-Yu. It's also a great type to use with Tera Blast for dealing damage to Chi-Yu.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Iron Moth deal with powerful Earthquakes from the likes of Ting-Lu and Garchomp, gives it a vital resistance to Water, and nullifies Spore. If using Tera Blast, it also can threaten Azumarill.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dark resistance can surprise Chien-Pao looking to revenge kill Iron Moth and protects it from powerful Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Baxcalibur, Dragapult, and Choice Band Dragonite.

  • Fire: Tera Fire's defensive benefits are not particularly helpful, but it makes late-game sweeping with Fiery Dance far more likely.

  • Poison: Tera Poison doesn't offer too many amazing defensive benefits beyond removing the irritating weaknesses to Water and Rock, but it does retain Iron Moth's valuable Toxic Spikes absorption powers and makes Black Sludge far more viable.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak protects Iron Moth from the dreaded Salt Cure, which can otherwise put a timer on phazing. It also prevents specially defensive Iron Moth from losing to Chi-Yu's flinch chance.

  • Passho Berry: Passho Berry lets Iron Moth survive most special Water-type attacks without needing to Terastallize, such as Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump, as well as weaker priority moves from Azumarill and Palafin-H.

  • Sitrus Berry: The quick burst of recovery Sitrus Berry gives can be paired with specialized EV spreads, allowing Iron Moth to survive a wider range of attacks.

  • Leftovers versus Black Sludge: Leftovers's residual recovery pairs well with using Whirlwind as much as possible, but it's a fairly high-value item. Black Sludge is an acceptable alternative, but note that it will hurt Iron Moth after Terastallization if not using Tera Poison.

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy can be paired with specialized EV spreads to either get easier KOs, gain a Speed boost, or survive surprising special attacks at the cost of the flexibility of more general EV spreads designed to switch in multiple times.

General EV Spread Examples

  • 236 HP / 228 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 36 Spe with Modest: This EV spread survives Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Psyshock from full health.

  • 196 HP / 132 SpD / 180 Spe with Calm: This EV spread almost always avoids the 2HKO from Modest Chi-Yu's Dark Pulse while outspeeding it alongside Jolly Baxcalibur and Jolly Great Tusk.

  • 244 HP / 164 SpD / 100 Spe with Timid: This EV spread outspeeds Jolly Annihilape and, as a bonus, gives Leftovers Iron Moth a nearly guaranteed chance to avoid being 2HKOed by Modest Chi-Yu's Dark Pulse and Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball.

  • 244 HP / 52 Def / 4 SpA / 12 SpD / 196 Spe with Timid: This EV spread sacrifices some bulk to outspeed Garchomp while still surviving Life Orb Chien-Pao's Throat Chop and having a great shot of surviving two uses of Dark Pulse from Timid Chi-Yu. It also gets a Speed boost from Quark Drive.

  • 236 HP / 236 Def / 36 Spe with Bold: This very physically defensive EV spread will allow a full health Iron Moth to survive Tera Dark Black Glasses Kingambit's Kowtow Cleave after Supreme Overlord has been boosted by two KOed teammates.

Sitrus Berry Exclusive EV Spreads

  • When using Sitrus Berry, make sure to run an even HP stat, so that one use of Ruination will activate it.

  • 180 HP / 228 Def / 100 Spe with Timid: This EV spread almost always survives two hits from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Throat Chop with Sitrus Berry, and it outspeeds Jolly Annihilape.

  • 244 HP / 188 Def / 12 SpA / 12 SpD / 52 Spe with Bold: This EV spread usually prevents Iron Moth from getting 2HKOed by Timid Flutter Mane's Psyshock and avoids a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's Throat Chop as well. The minor Special Defense investment also avoids a 2HKO from Modest Chi-Yu's Dark Pulse and Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball.

Booster Energy Exclusive EV Spreads

  • 188 HP / 244 Def / 36 SpA / 4 SpD / 36 Spe with Modest: This Booster Energy optimized spread OHKOes 4 Special Defense EVs Iron Bundle with a Quark Drive-boosted Fiery Dance while having good enough physical bulk to have a good chances of surviving powerful attacks from full health, like Timid Choice Specs Flutter Mane's Psyshock.

  • 252 HP / 220 SpD / 36 Spe with Calm: This EV spread gives Iron Moth a Special Defense boost with Quark Drive, making it so bulky that even a Modest Choice Specs Chi-Yu has a low chance of 2HKOing it with Dark Pulse!

Benchmarks for Speed EVs

Like many fast bulky Pokemon, Iron Moth has an huge variety of viable EV builds. If you'd like to make your own EV spread though, keep these Speed tiers in mind! Natures that can efficiently use these Speed tiers will be mentioned.

  • 36 Speed EVs with any Neutral Nature: This is the minimum amount of Speed to run, outspeeding Jolly Breloom.

  • 52 Speed EVs with any Neutral Nature: This outspeeds Modest Gholdengo.

  • 76 Speed EVs with Timid or 180 Speed EVs with Calm This outspeeds Modest Chi-Yu, Jolly Baxcalibur, and Jolly Great Tusk. Note that Timid will give Iron Moth a bonus point to Speed, but a Calm nature has a greater chance of surviving some special attacks with specific EV spreads.

  • 100 Speed EVs with Timid: This outspeeds Jolly Annihilape.

  • 132 Speed EVs with Timid: This is the minimum investment for Iron Moth to get a Speed boost from Quark Drive, assuming no Special Attack investment, since doing so will increase Special Attack instead.

  • 148 Speed EVs with Timid: This outspeeds Jolly Mimikyu.

  • 196 Speed EVs with Timid: This outspeeds Jolly Garchomp.

Iron Thorns.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here id s sample set that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

Baxcalibur.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out the format page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• Baxcalibur's bulk majorly differentiates it from Chien-Pao as an offensive Ice-type, making it a very relevant alternative.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear is recommended despite its inconsistent damage, as it deals damage through Mimikyu's disguise and potentially KOes Focus Sash users like Breloom and Meowscarada.

  • Glaive Rush: Glaive Rush makes Baxcalibur very vulnerable to getting KOed the next turn, but it is still the least risky Dragon-type STAB move. Remember that Ice Shard will remove Glaive Rush's negative effects as well.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency Without Focus Sash - High: While Baxcalibur's typing is very helpful against Iron Bundle, its a poor defensive typing otherwise, often forcing it to Terastallize against threats such as Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao.

  • Ground: A Ground Tera type gives Baxcalibur a reliable STAB move in Earthquake, resistance to Stealth Rock, and removes a ton of weaknesses, all at the cost of losing to Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle, and Rotom-W.

  • Electric: With Tera Electric, Baxcalibur's Tera Blast deals massive damage to Corviknight that lack a set up move, Azumarill, does good chip damage to Dondozo, and gains a valuable resistance to Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

  • Ice: Boosting the power of Ice Shard gives Choice Band Baxcalibur new revenge kill chances, and makes wall breaking with Icicle Spear easier.

  • Fire: Tera Fire massively swings the Scizor matchup in Baxcalibur's favor, makes it a good check against powerful Fire-types such as Iron Moth and Volcarona, and severely punishes Chi-Yu's attempts to revenge kill with Overheat.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Baxcalibur's bulk makes it an excellent user of Assault Vest, making it particularly effective against Rotom formes and Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Band: With Choice Band, Baxcalibur becomes an immediate threat, threatening to 2HKO physical walls such as Dondozo.

  • Focus Sash: Chien-Pao has an easier time running Focus Sash, but the sheer surprise value and less reliance on Terastallization still makes it a viable option on Baxcalibur.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This simple EV spread maximizes Baxcalibur's bulk and power.

  • 116 HP / 156 Atk / 236 Spe with Adamant: The Speed investment here outspeeds Modest Gholdengo and Adamant Dragonite.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: If using Focus Sash or Choice Band, winning Speed ties against Great Tusk and opposing Baxcalibur makes maximum Speed much more appealing.

sets.name: Sweeper
sets.description:
• With good bulk, an immunity to burn, and just enough Speed to work, Baxcalibur is a powerful sweeper.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear KOes Breloom and Mimikyu through Focus Sash and Disguise respectively.

  • Glaive Rush: While Glaive Rush is valuable for late-game sweeping, it does make Baxcalibur very vulnerable to bulky OHKO move users such as Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard means Baxcalibur will have a difficult time breaking past bulky Steel-types early-game, but it makes it an effective cleaner otherwise.

Other Options

  • Swords Dance: Dragon Dance is the more reliable option for sweeping due to Baxcalibur's Speed, but Swords Dance can be paired with Ice Shard and an Adamant nature to OHKO fast, frail foes such as Booster Energy Flutter Mane.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Terastallization is required for Baxcalibur to cover the most amount of threats via Tera Blast, and patches up its mediocre defensive typing, but Baxcalibur's bulk and tendency to force switches means it's still viable without it.

  • Ground: Tera Ground makes Earthquake an especially reliable sweeping tool, removes most of Baxcalibur's weaknesses, and makes it immune to Thunder Wave.

  • Electric: When paired with Tera Blast, this is Life Orb Baxcalibur's best shot at dealing damage to Dondozo switch-ins. The paralysis immunity also helps Baxcalibur set up against Blissey with less risk.

  • Ice: Tera Ice works great with Ice Shard, making Baxcalibur easier to clean teams with.

  • Steel: With a Tera type of Steel, Baxcalibur has a much better matchup against Flutter Mane and Mimikyu, and a handy resistance to Scizor's Bullet Punch.

  • Fire: Besides adding a useful Bullet Punch resistance, Tera Fire severely punishes powerful Fire-types that think they can revenge kill, and gives Baxcalibur a powerful Tera Blast against Corviknight and Tera Steel Rotom-W.

  • Dragon: This makes Glaive Rush deal obscene damage and removes weaknesses to Mach Punch and Bullet Punch.

Items

  • Loaded Dice: With a guaranteed 4 hits from Icicle Spear, Baxcalibur is able to always OHKO offensive Mimikyu after Dragon Dance.

  • Life Orb: This helps Baxcalibur sweep reliably and ensures Icicle Spear OHKOes Breloom through Focus Sash.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash may seem like a waste with Baxcalibur's bulk, but it provides new set up opportunities and eases match-ups against other Dragon-types.

Gholdengo.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• With Trick and an immunity to status moves, Gholdengo is a dangerous Choice item attacker for offensive and stall teams alike!

  • Focus Blast: Though its accuracy can be an issue, Focus Blast is the best way around Dark-types that resist Steel-type attacks, such as Chi-Yu and Kingambit, in addition to dealing severe damage to Ting-Lu before it Terastallizes.

  • Thunderbolt: This 2HKOes Dondozo and deals serious damage to Toxapex and Quaquaval.

  • Nasty Plot: This can be used to give Gholdengo more bite against defensive, slower teams after using Trick.

  • Neutral Nature and Nature Mints: Use a neutral nature Gholdengo that has a Timid or Modest Mint used on it. This way, Gholdengo can eat any Berry without being confused after Trick.

Other Options

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam deals massive damage to Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon, and pairs well with Tera Fairy.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Choice Gholdengo is perfectly functional without Terastallizing, it's particularly vulnerable to common Pokemon that Terastallization can solve such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Gholdengo gains an extremely useful immunity to Ground, which is especially useful on Choice Specs sets and against users of Fissure such as Dondozo.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Gholdengo a vital resistance to Sucker Punch, and an option to use the more reliable Tera Blast against Kingambit.

  • Normal: A Normal Tera type gives Gholdengo the edge against opposing Ghost-types, at the cost of becoming very vulnerable to Breloom's Mach Punch.

  • Ghost: The extra damage from Shadow Ball can make Gholdengo a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is a useful way to resist Sucker Punch without being weak to Fairy-type attacks from Flutter Mane.

  • Water: This Tera type gives Gholdengo a valuable resistance to Fire, massively improving the matchup against Chi-Yu.

  • Steel: Make It Rain becomes very powerful with a Tera boost, at the cost of making Gholdengo vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With this, Gholdengo outspeeds key threats such as Dragapult, Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane. It also outspeeds Chien-Pao and Meowscarada, but beware of Sucker Punch.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs make Gholdengo much more difficult to wall, with foes such as Dondozo getting 2HKOed.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Gholdengo mirror matches are common enough that maximizing Speed is usually a wise idea. Timid is needed to outspeed Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult.

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 204 SpA / 36 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: This bulkier spread for Choice Specs sets allows Gholdengo to survive an unboosted Shadow Ball from Timid Flutter Mane, while outspeeding Adamant Breloom and Jolly Tyranitar.

  • 36 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 44 SpD / 172 Spe with Timid: This spread allows Choice Scarf Gholdengo to outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane while being able survive Tera Water or Choice Specs boosted Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle.

  • 68 HP / 4 Def / 148 SpA / 36 SpD / 252 Spe with Modest: This spread survives an unboosted Shadow Ball from Timid Flutter Mane 93.7% of the time while also outspeeding Breloom.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo a terror against slower teams, especially with its good bulk, unpredictable coverage, and diverse Tera Types.

  • Focus Blast: Despite its reliability issues, Focus Blast lets Gholdengo defeat Kingambit, and hits Chi-Yu switch ins very hard.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Gholdengo avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure and eases prediction in general.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock lets Gholdengo break through Blissey and Clodsire more easily.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Gholdengo may have a great typing, but common Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu will usually revenge kill it without Terastallization.

  • Flying: Flying Gholdengo gets the jump on dangerous Earthquake users such as Ting-Lu, Garchomp, Dragonite, and Great Tusk.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is unlikely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping, and Gholdengo has a much better match-up against Chien-Pao and Ting-Lu.

  • Normal: While it's a much worse defensive typing, Tera Normal does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types like Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, at the cost of being weak to Mach Punch.

  • Water: With this Tera type and Tera Blast, Chien-Pao, Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Moth have a much harder time revenge killing Gholdengo.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak prevents Salt Cure from chipping down Gholdengo, making it far easier for it to run Recover against Garganacl.

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon ruins Breloom's chances of winning the lead war against Gholdengo and makes Hippowdon easy setup bait.

  • Leftovers: This is the most reliable option for keeping Gholdengo healthy and pairs especially well with Substitute.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Gholdengo's good bulk, Focus Sash is useful for giving it new opportunities to sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 204 SpA / 36 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: For sets with Recover, this bulkier spread can make sense, allowing Gholdengo to survive Shadow Ball from Flutter Mane that lack an offensive item, and outpacing Adamant Breloom and Jolly Tyranitar.

  • 252 HP / 172 Def / 52 SpA / 28 SpD / 4 Spe with Modest: This bulky spread survives a Shadow Ball from Modest Flutter Mane assuming it lacks an offensive boost and can use Terastallization to avoid a 2HKO from Focus Sash Chien-Pao's STAB attacks.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Speed is useful on more offensive sets to at least speedtie with opposing Gholdengo, and outspeeding several threats close to this Speed tier, such as Dragonite.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• While Gholdengo's defensive stats aren't remarkable, it's fantastic typing and immunity to status moves like Taunt make it a great defensive Pokemon.

  • Thunder Wave: This makes switching into this Gholdengo very difficult, as it can punish its speedier offensive checks like Chi-Yu and Meowscarada.

  • Hex versus Shadow Ball: Hex gives this Gholdengo a good offensive kick against paralyzed foes, but Shadow Ball is worth considering for its consistency.

  • Make It Rain versus Focus Blast: Make It Rain is Gholdengo's most consistent way of dealing damage to Garganacl, but this set's defensive nature makes it difficult to win the one-on-one. Focus Blast isn't nearly as reliable, but it's Gholdengo's best shot at making it past Kingambit and Ting-Lu, and punishing Chi-Yu switch-ins.

  • EV Spread: The given EVs outspeed paralyzed Dragapult, while maximizing physical bulk.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: Despite Gholdengo's fantastic typing, Chien-Pao is easily able to break through any Gholdengo that doesn't Terastallize.

  • Fighting: Beyond boosting Focus Blast's power, it provides Gholdengo with a vital Dark-type resistance.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Gholdengo a much better matchup against Dark-type attackers like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada.

  • Flying: Avoiding Earthquake against foes like Garchomp makes Tera Flying extremely useful for Gholdengo; this also gives it protection against Fissure from the likes of Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is not incredible defensively, but it does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Mimikyu.

  • Water: Tera Water is the best Fire-type resistant Tera type for Gholdengo, letting it potentially survive an assault from Chi-Yu and Iron Moth, though their coverage moves will still seriously damage Gholdengo.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet takes advantage of Gholdengo's excellent typing against physical moves, making it a good way to punish contact moves such as Outrage from Garchomp.

  • Covert Cloak: This is Gholdengo's best shot of outstalling Garganacl, since it grants an immunity to Salt Cure's effect.

  • Weakness Policy: While this might seem strange on a defensive Pokemon, Weakness Policy lets Gholdengo beat opposing Gholdengo as long as they lack Choice Specs.

Wo-Chien.overview:
This analysis is for the Regulation C format of Battle Stadium Singles, which lasts until June 30th, 2023. For more information on this format and its current events, check out this page!

If you feel this analysis is missing anything important or needs an update, feel free to suggest any changes here.

sets.name: Leech Seed
sets.description:
• With excellent bulk and a unique array of moves to support it, Wo-Chien stands out as a dangerous user of Leech Seed and a prime Pokemon to stall matches out with.

  • Foul Play versus Knock Off: Foul Play is Wo-Chien's most consistent offensive move that also happens to punish setup sweepers, while Knock Off's support is especially helpful against Trick users such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W. Note that both are viable together if you're willing to give up a support move.

  • Substitute: When paired together with Toxic Spikes, Protect and Substitute makes even foes that should beat Wo-Chien get worn down before they can KO it, such as Chi-Yu. Substitute itself protects Wo-Chien from slow users of Yawn such as Dondozo and Hippowdon, and slow OHKO moves from Ting-Lu, Dondozo, and Kingambit.

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Wo-Chien powerful chipping down potential, though it should never be used as Wo-Chien's only attack due to it being extremely difficult to KO with. When paired with Knock Off, it's especially useful against Wo-Chien mirror matches.

  • Giga Drain: With Stealth Rock support, Giga Drain OHKOes Iron Bundle and almost always 2HKOes Chien-Pao. If you allocate 60 EVs to Special Attack, Giga Drain will OHKO Iron Bundle regardless of Stealth Rock.

  • Taunt: Taunt does an excellent job of surprising other Taunt Pokemon switching in, such as Annihilape and Corviknight.

  • Toxic Spikes Partners: Wo-Chien becomes far more deadly with Toxic Spikes support, letting it quickly wear down a wide variety of foes even faster. Toxapex is one of the best options thanks to its good defensive synergy with Wo-Chien, but other options include Iron Moth, Glimmora, Clodsire, Focus Sash Meowscarada, and the niche Gengar.

Other Options

  • Snarl: Snarl makes fearsome special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu far easier to switch into when Wo-Chien needs to escape, though Wo-Chien will need to have the correct Tera Type to outstall these foes itself.

  • Ingrain: In addition to providing some extra recovery, Ingrain makes phazers such as Ting-Lu and Hippowdon fail to stop Wo-Chien consistently, though Wo-Chien being trapped is a serious drawback.

Tera Types

  • Tera Dependency - High: Despite Wo-Chien's fantastic bulk, its vulnerability to Toxic Spikes and poor defensive typing mean it must often Terastallize to stall out teams.

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a vital resistance to Fairy and Fighting, and it also lets Wo-Chien absorb Toxic Spikes.

  • Fairy: Besides being a great defensive type, Tera Fairy helps Wo-Chien against Fighting-types that'd normally beat it.

  • Water: Tera Water provides Ice and Fire resistances, helpful against Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives useful resistances to Fairy, Fire, and Ice, which help against major threats like Flutter Mane, Baxcalibur, Chi-Yu, and Chien-Pao.

Items

  • Leftovers: Wo-Chien's stalling playstyle makes Leftovers the most consistent recovery item.

  • Big Root: If another Pokemon desperately needs Leftovers, Big Root is a viable alternative for getting extra recovery from Leech Seed and Giga Drain.

EV Spreads and Adjustments

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish or Bold: Maximizing Wo-Chien's physical bulk lets it pull off some incredible stunts, such as avoiding a 3HKO from Breloom's Mach Punch with Leftovers and, after Terastallization, avoiding a 2HKO from Choice Band Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful or Calm: With the correct Tera Type and maximum Special Defense, Wo-Chien can take on Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle much more effectively.

  • Using 60 SpA EVs: If you're willing to give up a bit of bulk, this investment is required to OHKO Iron Bundle with Giga Drain with either a Bold or a Calm nature.

  • Using 100 Speed EVs: With some sacrifice to bulk, this Speed investment lets Wo-Chien outspeed Adamant maximum Speed Kingambit, and it can be vital in Wo-Chien mirror matches after Terastallization makes it vulnerable to Leech Seed, due to Substitute blocking Leech Seed.

Chien-Pao.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: RUINOUS ATTACKER
sets.description:
• With its high Attack and Speed, and incredible ability in Sword of Ruin, Chien-Pao is one of the strongest physical attackers in the game.

  • Icicle Crash: While Ice Spinner is perfectly accurate, Icicle Crash’s higher power and flinch chance makes it the preferred attack. Additionally, not being a contact move allows Chien-Pao to avoid unnecessary chip damage from Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sucker Punch vs Crunch: Sucker Punch offers priority with a strong base power at the cost of necessitating prediction, while Crunch is a more standard attack whose Defense drop can allow Chien-Pao to potentially break through bulky foes.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard is a more consistent albeit weaker alternative to Sucker Punch.

  • Sacred Sword: Sacred Sword provides coverage for Pokemon that resist one or both of Chien-Pao’s STAB attacks, like Heatran, Chi-Yu, and other Chien-Pao. Additionally, ignoring defense boosts allows Chien-Pao to deal more consistent damage to foes who boost their Defense.

  • Swords Dance: While it can be difficult to fit and very reliant on Focus Sash, Swords Dance boosts Chien-Pao’s Attack to unwallable levels, making it a very potent sweeper.

  • 0-1 SpA IV: If using Tera Blast on Jolly Chien-Pao, make sure to to use a SpA IV that's 0-1. This is because if Flutter Mane uses Charm, any SpA IV that's higher will result in Tera Blast becoming a Special Attack.

Other Options

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop disables the use of sound-based moves from targets like Skeledirge and Sylveon, but these matchups are so uncommon that it generally isn't worth using over Crunch.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner can be used as a more consistent Ice STAB, however it makes Chien-Pao more vulnerable to Rocky Helmet users.

  • Sheer Cold: While it may seem alluring, Sheer Cold is usually a waste of a slot on Chien-Pao sets like this, as its standard attacks already hit most relevant foes. Even if Chien-Pao fails to KO a foe, it will generally leave it within range for a teammate.

Tera Types

  • With few exceptions, Chien-Pao is about all-out offense. However, its choice of item drastically affects its strategy. Tera Types have been organized by item choice to better clarify how each Tera Type works in that context.

Tera Types for Focus Sash and Life Orb

  • Tera Dependency - Low: Chien-Pao offers power in spades without needing to Terastallize, only needing it on very rare occasions to break past specific walls or dodge priority moves aimed at it.

  • Electric: Tera Electric can be used in tandem with Tera Blast to improve Chien-Pao’s matchup against key threats such as Urshifu-R and Dondozo while also making it immune to paralysis.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost doesn’t offer much offensive benefit, but it allows Chien-Pao to dodge Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, which can be particularly useful if using Swords Dance.

  • Grass: Tera Grass lets Chien-Pao survive Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes, which otherwise threatens to OHKO through Focus Sash. Combined with Tera Blast, Chien-Pao still threatens big damage into Urshifu-R and Dondozo.

  • Dark: Tera Dark boosts Sucker Punch to extreme power levels while making Crunch exceptionally difficult to switch into without a resistance.

  • Ice: Tera Ice can allow Chien-Pao to finish foes off with Ice Shard from higher ranges and makes Icicle Crash an even more formidable tool.

Tera Types for Choice Band

  • Tera Dependency - Medium: While Chien-Pao is already plenty powerful, Choice Band combined with Tera can elevate 2HKOs to OHKOs on some of the bulkiest walls in the meta. For this reason, Tera can be worth using on Choice Band sets.

  • Dark: Tera Dark turns Choice Band Crunch into a devastating wallbreaker move that few can withstand, OHKOing Max HP Annihilape and Scizor if using an Adamant nature. Neutralizing Chien-Pao’s Steel-type weakness also makes it less vulnerable to Scizor’s Bullet Punch.

  • Ice: Tera Ice gives Choice Band Icicle Crash enough power to challenge even physically defensive Ting-Lu, having approximately a 69% chance to OHKO if using an Adamant nature; be warned, however, that Ting-Lu often Terastallizes in front of Chien-Pao, making this inconsistent. The extra power behind Ice Shard is also a welcome boost.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy combined with Choice Band Tera Blast handily defeats some of Chien-Pao's less common checks, OHKOing standard variants of Annihilape and Assault Vest Iron Hands. It also removes several weaknesses, most notably turning Chien-Pao's 4x Fighting-type weakness into a resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly or Adamant: This offensive spread works with all standard sets. Adamant gives Chien-Pao a significant power boost, but Jolly is important for Speed tying with Flutter Mane and opposing Chien-Pao.

  • 252 Atk / 68 Def / 188 Spe with Adamant: This alternate spread is commonly associated with Choice Band, fully maximizing Attack while still maintaining enough Speed to outrun Timid Iron Moth. When used with an appropriate Tera type, the Defense investment lets Chien-Pao survive Life Orb Mimikyu's Play Rough into Shadow Sneak.

Ting-Lu.overview:
This Pokemon has been updated for Regulation D! If you have any questions or feel it needs more updates, feel free to post here.

For more information on Battle Stadium Singles, visit the format page!

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu's absurd bulk and excellent support movepool make it the premier Stealth Rock setter in the metagame!

  • Ruination: Ruination gives Ting-Lu the most consistent option for damage output, without resorting to offensive investment.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam deals serious damage to Fairy-types, with Flutter Mane in particular needing a huge amount of defensive investment to avoid being OHKOed by it.
